description: Good wifi, friendly service, and coffee.  Luckily they had fresh cookies today and hit the spot.  Right downtown in the mission so close to every thing.
author: Jeffrey T.

description:
This place should just close and get replaced by a better cafe with staff who actually want to work.

I stopped by because I really had to go use the bathroom. I read on their bathroom door that you had to be a customer only. So I went to the front to order something, only to find out it's cash only. I rarely carry cash and this was my problem #2 on my quest to find a bathroom.

I turned around to walk away and told my friends how difficult it was to find a bathroom around here. My friend was digging through her purse and found some cash to lend me, I went up again to buy a drink.

Then the staff tells me "it's ok, I don't need it," so I interpret this as him just letting me use the bathroom without buying anything. I was really appreciative that he would be so kind to make an exception for me. So I proceeded to the back to use the bathroom.

Then I hear him yelling at me so I get closer to listen. He says "i don't want your business!" I was surprised to encounter someone so ill tempered. 

I was polite, offered to pay as soon as I realized I could afford to, and tried my best to follow their policies. People like that should not be in the service industry and definitely not doing any good for the business.
author: Sarah P.

description:
There are dozens of amazing coffee shops around 24th Street BART. This is not one of them.

Bad coffee - the worst cappuccino I've ever had in SF.
Rude staff - like, impressively so. The cashier was downright mean to the couple in front of me. All over them asking about the biscotti? Why?
Broken wifi - it seems some people were able to get work done, but I was not among them.
Oh, and did I mention the bad coffee?

Sometimes you walk into a place and you notice it's only half full. Sometimes, that means you got lucky. Other times, that means the place is not worth your time.
author: Zach M.

description: This sad excuse for a cafe was the worst place I have ever encountered, my daughter and I had entered in hopes of finding a bathroom when we came across one of the rudest baristas in mankind, she wouldn't let us use the restroom r((,6 y,y CLC;; u
author: Shanti H.

description: A little bit of artsy mixed with yummy, affordable coffee. Free WiFi and a public bathroom should be noted and praised. The iced mocha drink was everything I hoped for and it was an awesome little place to hang out. The wall is open for local bands and businesses to advertise which adds a local touch. Plenty of seating and although I didn't try any of the food, it all looked yummy. To be totally honest, there's not too much to say about this place, the drinks were out in 5 minutes and I liked the atmosphere but nothing special? Just your average café I suppose but it was a great stop after lots of walking on Valencia.
author: Cara H.

description: I am bummed to have to write this because I have no idea what happened to this cafe. It used to be one of my favorites. The service is so bad now. They are dismissive (maybe just stoned?) You get the feeling that they really don't want to talk to you. They overly too-cool-for-kindness dude eventually kinda threw the order at me. It is such a bummer there... just go somewhere else. The neighborhood has many better options.
author: Laura B.

description:
Visiting San Francisco for a week from Austin, and this place has a great atmosphere for my morning ritual and for a couple of half day work sessions. I was there at open every day for a week and Najeet greeted me every day and was just a great person- by week end I felt like she was a good friend. Coffee is good, priced right, and consistent. Good WiFi, not too loud, and Najeet runs a tight ship. Everything is meticulous every morning and it is one of the few businesses I noticed that cleaned the sidewalk in front every day. Nice to see unpretentious pride in this little shop. 
This place is exactly what a good neighborhood coffee shop should be, in my opinion.
author: Jack M.

description: I come to this Cafe all the time. I usually enjoy my experience and get a bagel and cream cheese and a cup of coffee multiple times a week. I advise you to only go there when the woman is working because the man will get your order wrong. Today I told him it was allergic to poppy seeds. He DOESN'T KNOW WHAT AN ALLERGY IS! I even had to explain to him what an allergy was and that I would get very sick if I got poppy seeds. He told me that there were no poppy seeds on my bagel but the bagel was filled inside out w them. I took medication that need to be eaten with food and I needed something to eat so now I'm going to be sick for the rest of the day. I wish that I didn't tip and I'm a phenomenal Tipper. I waited 15 mins for my bagel which made me late to work. The woman is always fast, courteous, friendly, and gets me out the door. But the one woman is not working I will never be coming back to this establishment. I hope the owner of this establishment realizes that I could sue and close them
author: Amber A.

description:
To all my one-star reviewers out there: PREACH.

Customer service is absolute trash. It's not in their cafe business acumen. Hours online? Wrong. It closes at 10pm and not 11pm and the cashier will wait for you to order your drink and announce he's closing 5 min after. Nowhere in the cafe does it say its hours either, and when we told him we were confused by the time, he just gave us a blank stare and went back to cleaning.

Cashier we had tonight had trash service; if it weren't for his facial expression of utter disdain, I probably would've thought he was a mute. Just absolutely one of the rudest cashiers. If you see a 5'7'' (I'm giving him the benefit of the doubt here with his height) brown hair tatted guy, just leave the cafe. Per other reviews, apparently there's also a woman there who is disliked by many, so I highly question who's hiring these personnel.

Customer service makes the entire experience. And this place needs better people who actually understands what it takes to be in the service industry.
author: Lily Y.

description: I like the coffee and the sweets , but it reeks of BO! It made me sick to my stomach!
author: Pooh W.

description: Their server James is a bigot who just aggressively asked the only black customer to leave. The customer came and sat down while James wasn't at the counter, but when James returned and saw him he said that "this ain't the free library. Get the hell out of here."
author: Taj W.

description: The environment is really nothing to get hyped up here but it's cheap and in a convenient location. The staff is somewhat nice, the restroom is okay, and overall it's just alright. I have nothing amazing to say about this place but also nothing terrible.
author: Nicholas L.

description: Around 9:00pm I have a coffee in this place, bad customer service and racism. I ordered a coffee with cream and he gave me a coffee without cream. Mr. said that I would milk the coffee. I asked for a code for the wifi and he gave me one that did not work. Negroes are definitely not welcome in this place
author: Yuri M.

description: Cash only, bathroom looks like a prison (that you have to be buzzed into) and has no toilet paper or paper towels. Awful experience!!
author: Drea L.

description:
Probably the Sketchiest Coffee Shop I've been to. 

I don't mind the "Not turning on the lights" to save some energy. 
I don't mind the open network Wifi everyone gets on. 
I don't mind you just have one person working the counter early morning. 
I don't mind you have to get the key from the lady over the counter to use the shared restroom.

But seriously, please put in toilet paper for your paying customers.  I ended up going to Cafetazo couple of doors down and bought another coffee just to use their restroom. Other than that, it's a decent coffee shop in line with the locals
author: Pete S.

description:
Somehow I'm supposed to log on to the WiFi with a Login Code from the cashier. I'm writing this review using at&t data. Not working. Could be that too many people are signed into the muddy waters guest WiFi, too lazy to figure it out. I got a tea which is good and an espresso shot which was okay. Now I'm wondering if someone who just showed up will be able to log onto the WiFi. To be continued.

Update: she's not able to log on.
author: Lewis G.

description: I came to this place in the search of WiFi. Their WiFi doesn't work. I also tried using their bathroom, which doesn't lock and anyone, as it happened, can open the door at any time. Their coffee and pastries are average. I wouldn't come here again.
author: Diego C.

description: I needed to use the restroom and chose to hop in line before buying something. I was planning to buy a cookie immediately after, but of course the owner just had to aggressively run up to me in line. She was super rude to me and proceeded to speak poorly about me while I was in line for my cookie. Retched customer service and a sub par cookie. Also, I never write nasty reviews. Take a look. I have only written 5 star reviews to date.
author: Maritza M.

description: Man, I really wanted to like this place. Unfortunately, the staff member working tonight was so rude I left before I ordered anything. Just unbelievably rude. I came with a group of friends excited to try it and I was so embarrassed.
author: Kent M.

description: The staff is always friendly, and the coffee is fresh! I don't get the negative reviews, some are outright lies. They have free wifi, with a code, for 3 hours. The only negative thing; some of their customers. Have seen many "business meetings" here, with few people ordering, but taking up space and being loud. But that's the tech community in San Francisco; wanting the experience for free, taking up space from the local community.
author: Douglas A.

description: Yummy soy latte! I got one nearly every morning during a work stay in the mission. The lady behind the counter is super fast and remembers everyone's drink (impressive!!). Friendly, slightly grimy place. Lots of character. I've not tried any of the food options so I can't speak to those. Cash only so come prepared
author: Katie R.

description: These reviews are hilarious. Like sitting on a bus??? Good lord....Happy to see this place is still around despite the neighborhood changes. I needed a place to hang in the Mission for a couple of hours to read and did not want third wave garbage or to sit amongst a sea of laptops. This is what a coffee shop should be.
author: Jackie A.

description: My favorite coffee stop on Valencia! Among my top 3 favorite in all of San Francisco! Very friendly service, I'm new to San Francisco but they treat me as if I've been a regular for years!
author: Cory H.

description: I came here with my friend to study. It says it's open until 11 pm and he saw us come in with all our books and unpack all our school materials. He waited until we bought our coffee to announce he's closing in 10 minutes. 2 hours before the said time on yelp. We came here to study and he saw that. I felt so disrespected and I'm never spending another cent at this cafe again. Come here to study at your own risk!
author: Angelica R.

description: Good coffee and great desserts. Stopped by after walking for a few hours. Relaxed vibe made it a great place to catch up with out of town friends.
author: Michael S.

description: Needed some coffee for an afternoon pick-me-up and happened to see this place across the street. It wasn't too busy on a Saturday afternoon so the service was quick. I got an iced almond milk latte which was delicious; the coffee here is surprisingly good. The lady working behind the counter was super friendly and helpful, especially with my annoying dietary restrictions. The place does look a bit divey but it's a good option for coffee in a relaxing space. I didn't try the food since I had eaten recently, but would like to next time. Cash only, like so many places in the area, but they do have an ATM. Very unassuming place in the Mission with great coffee - check it out!
author: Pooja C.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE ! Muddy waters is so San Franciscan the 
service is great, the coffee is to die for. Love the music , and the just relaxed feel you get.
author: Mary R.

description:
I had the worst hot chocolate ever in my life. Just hot water with some flavor. And it is cash only! What year are we in??!!  I had to throw the shitty hot chocolate cup after 2 sips, when I got home I had a bad stomach ache .Never coming back to this place!!
Also, the lady who was serving, was so rude. Not a polite sentence came out from her mouth. What a waste of time and money on this place.
author: Reda D.

description: There is wifi here but it's not free - you get a code with every purchase (and the code only works on one device). i.e. l have to buy three items to get wifi on my laptop/phone/iPad.
author: Jessica C.

description:
Great spot to get work done! What else can you ask for?
Yelp asks me to write more so here it goes again... Great place to grind it out.
author: Arshia M.

description:
Don't listen to these reviews. This place is fine. Needed a decently quiet place to do a video chat for work. Stopped in and had no issues. Plenty of space, outlets near every table...wifi name and password right next to the register. The woman working the counter was quite amiable. Wifi didn't shut off after an hour as prior reviewers asserted. 

"One-fifth of the people are against everything, all the time"- Bobby Kennedy
author: Justin W.

description: The coffee is terrible and it smells like bathroom disinfectant
author: Traun L.

description:
wifi? it is free only for an hour but even during that time it was so slow I was not able to use it. friendly staff? nope. coffee? horrible tasting, it was burnt and old. atmosphere: dirty, everything was just so dirty, i felt like i was sitting on the bus. it was big but you would not have problems even if it was small: no one wants to go there. i promise. this place is sad.
food: as bad as the coffee.
it was cash only and everything was expensive for what it was.

the owner obviously did not want to put any effort in making this place a pleasant place for customers.
author: Helia S.

description:
This review is about the INCREDIBLE amount of disability discrimination for wheelchair users this business is guilty of.

First let me say that I am a huge supporter of local coffee shops in the Mission.  I have been going here, the Muddys on 24th, Cafe La Boheme, Cafe Tazo, and others for many years.  I have never come across something like this before:

This place has a huge ledge at the door so wheelchair users cannot get inside.  Why they don't install a *tiny* concrete ramp (which would cost less than $50 and be a tax write-off) is beyond me.  Instead, if you are privy to the inside-scoop, they will bring you a fold out ramp.  Or so I thought.

A couple weeks ago I asked for an employee named Nick to bring me the fold out ramp.  I was astonished when he firmly said "NO!"  I use a wheelchair every day for traveling but can walk short distances to the bathroom and such (it is painful to walk because I have nerve damage in my legs).

"I've seen you walk before!  I'm not getting the ramp.  You can walk in here and leave your wheelchair outside."

My jaw nearly hit the floor.  I asked to talk to his supervisor and so he called her and put her on the phone.  I explained the situation and she seemed slightly bothered (though not outright upset) with what was happening.

Nick picked up the ramp and brought it over finally and said "I'm only doing this because otherwise you will sue us or something stupid like that."

I told him he did not know about my condition and that it caused me pain to walk.  I asked him if it caused him pain to bring me the ramp.

"It causes me mental anguish" he said.

I called the manager again after this and told her about his behavior.  She said it was a problem and that she would call me tomorrow to talk to me about it.
Well that was weeks ago.  She never called back and this jerk still works there, so I cannot feel safe and welcome in this space.  

It's heart breaking to know the management continues to let someone who discriminates against customers with disabilities work here.  They should also just make a permanent ramp so wheelchair using customers actually know they can enter the space.

Here is a picture I took of the entrance:
author: Thomas T.

description: An okay option for a place to work with wifi. Typical coffee choices, with a few food options. Not super atmospheric or exciting.
author: Breanne C.

description: The coffee is so-so. The coffee cake is not bad.  The cafe closes at 10 ish even though yelp said 11p!   The upside is a lot of tables.
author: Wing W.

description: It is open until late and a convenient location. Slightly noisy but there are enough tables in the back.
author: Mete R.

description:
$1 extra for almond milk?!? 

Crazy expensive. More expensive than Starbucks. Come on. I know it's the mission so everything is more expensive but this place is a dive.
author: Dee K.

description:
WARNING: THERE HAS BEEN A CHANGE

They've now instituted a one-hour time limit for use of the Wi-Fi. This is done through a one-time login code. You will be kicked off after an hour.

I should have known something was up when I walked in and found the place virtually empty. I'm a regular customer but hadn't been here in probably several weeks.

I come here from time to time to get work done on my laptop. I'm always very good about "feeding the meter" by making more purchases the longer I stay. I'm not one of those people who buys a small coffee and stays 12 hours.

I usually either bring a laptop to get work done or take a tablet and relax by surfing the web while drinking my coffee.

The coffee certainly isn't as good as say Four Barrel down the street. They can get away with no wi-fi as they draw people in through their coffee.

The draw for Muddy Waters was that it was a down-to-earth place where you could work or read for a few hours. These days, that often entails use of the Internet. A one-hour time limit causes you to feel like you are rushing against time rather than being able to relax.

There are a ton of coffee shops here in the City. Now, I can't think of a good reason to visit this one.

The bathroom is filthy. The food is mediocre. The coffee is just ok. Half of the customers should consider bathing more than once a month.

Farewell, Muddy Waters.
author: Fred M.

description:
My friend and I went in and they did not have anything we wanted from the menu, so we just asked what they did have. Their reasoning was they just have not updated the board in months, as many of the items have been out of stock for months. No apologies, just we don't have it, we haven't had it, and we probably won't be getting it back. 

Also, I had to use the restroom while I was there, there was a note on the door, but I did not understand what I needed to do to use the restroom, so I went to the counter to inquire. Apparently, you must go to the counter to be buzzed into the restroom. I am not sure why the sign did not just direct you to do so.
author: Linh S.

description: In many ways, I am happy some people here don't like it. I love that this Old school San Francisco cultural cafe has stayed in the area . Much better here than the snobs at other third wave coffees with their Macbooks.
author: Dom R.

description:
With only 1 staff holding down the fort, this place seems a bit run down. Drinks are mediocre. The reason why I keep coming back is because of seating. This place can fit like 100 people. Seating all around the perimeter and wall outlets everywhere!

CASH ONLY!
author: Anna H.

description:
NOTE: Great for locals and people who are chill and unpretentious. NOT good for Tech-Bros, Marina types, etc. 

The "homeless" that some of these customers are complaining about are what we in the Mission call "locals" or people who has lived in this neighbourhood far longer than any of these entitled, gentrifying twats. 
Unlike some other coffee shops...they are welcomed and treated with respect even if they don't look young and hip. 

I've been coming here regularly for years and know most of the staff. Nicest people you'll ever meet that treat you like family if you treat them with respect (especially the tattooed guy that a few customers complained about). Don't like it? Take BART a few stops to downtown...there's a few Starbucks and Peet's to make you feel at home with their uniforms to remind them that they are subservient to you. *gets off soapbox*

TL;DR 
If you're cool with them...they'll be cool with you. 
Coffee is good. Free Wi-Fi. Lots of outlets. Open late.
author: Rubeun T.

description:
This joint should be in downtown SF, just the right vibe: 
Bums outside. Bums inside. Therefore - smell. 
Place needs renovation (needed it 10 years ago).
By nyc standarts - this place should be rated "D" (look at the counter tops). 
Rude tanned skin barista. 
Icing on the top - Mediocre coffee, for cash only. 
___________________________________________
Save your day by not entering this s** whole.
author: Zhenya V.

description:
The guy w/the lame tattoos and in the plaid shirt from earlier pictures is a giant deuche 
never going there again 
gonna look for managers # and ask for my money back
author: Laura V.

description:
Wonderful coffee shop in the heart of the mission. If you're kind to the staff (as you should be), they'll be kind back. They have little patience for rude customers (and rightly so).

This isn't some fancy, shiny new coffee shop. This is classic mission. Free wifi. Cash only, but there's an ATM. If you're gonna sit for a spell and work on your laptop, it's only fair to tip accordingly.
author: Scott S.

description: Cashier was very rude. I brought my whole family for a few drinks. After a while the cashier stopped answering me and mugged me in front of my family. There was no line and he was purposely moving slow. He left me hanging and my dad had to get up and ask for an extra cup. He started staring down my dad before handing a cheap clear plastic water cup.
author: Vivek G.

description:
Their drinks are bad and the people that work there are rude. 

This is my least favorite coffee shop in the mission. I only went to this place because they have good hours but i prefer to walk further to get to "it's tops" to avoid this place. Totally don't recommend.
author: Diva H.

description:
Everyone who works here is extremely rude. I've had several bad experience with the staff. If you come in and sit down and take out a laptop, they'll come over and yell at you to buy something. 

Food and coffee is sub par. Avoid at all costs. If you need to work late, go to Its Tops.
author: Russ F.

description:
Note to Tonite's Cashier: 
Being miserable does not give you the right to hassle customers & could IN FACT cause you a world of hurt you are not ready for. Just saying.


This is my 2nd run-in with the same shitty guy w/ his shitty miserable outlook on life.  About 3 weeks ago I stopped by to grab drinks with a friend...condescending rude smart ass.  For no reason....but we laughed it off because it was simply unwarranted.  Felt sorry for him actually.

Today I walk in and see him hawk-eying me from across the room as I sit down (I was on a long distance phone call w/ mom).  About an hour later he makes it a point to come and ask me if he could "get me something" (already w/ the presumptive attitude that I'm just loitering....).  My "no thanks"  leads to "---everyone else here has bought something & this place is for paying customers".  Really, dude?   After I tell him I'm heading out cause I could feel myself getting hot....he's gonna get loud and say I can leave if I don't like it.  Dumb fuck----just said I was leaving.  And don't underestimate a Pretty Face, ya punk bitch! I  was actually just getting settled in from another cafe...trying to space out my drinks...and didn't appreciate him glaring at me the whole time I sat there.  I'm not about to be bullied by ANYONE.  Ya heard.

Note to Cashier:

You might catch someone on the wrong day so take it easy. Just saying'.
author: Chapstiq G.

description:
I don't generally write Yelp reviews but I just came from the place after a terrible experience.    My reason for going to the coffee shop was to use the Wi-Fi until the place closed at 11 pm.  Well around 9:30 pm I arrive and ask for decaf.   The guy at the counter didn't like that idea and went "looking" for some decaf.  When I asked him how long ago the decaf was made he said "I dunno mid-afternoon".   He would not make me a pour-over.  So to get a decaf I had to get a capucino - I paid for a large but got a very small cup.   About 10 minutes to 10 the guy started yelling that the place would close - everyone get ready.   Then to my horror, as I was sitting right next to the speaker, at 10 pm he BLASTED the music, indicating it was time to leave.  And he never turned it down.  I had to yell to ask him why he wasn't closing at 11 pm like the website said and he replied that "it was slow".   It was only slow cause he had kicked out about 8 tables.  I asked him to turn down the music while I went to collect my stuff.  He either didn't hear me or ignored me. 
How can this place make money?   They have no regard for their customers.  Starbucks might be corporate or whatever, but they know how to treat their customers.  This place does not.
author: Joyce S.

description:
Happy to report that this is an affordable coffee shop open decently late (11pm when the others around here close at 8pm). 

STAFF: pretty nice! -- nice enough to ask me how my night was going. Even though my night could've been going better, it was nice of him to ask. 

WI-FI: quite generous at 12Mbps down / 1Mbps up. There are also plenty of outlets to plug in. Would recommend if you're in the area and need a place to duck into. 

CON: cash only...so be prepared (or otherwise hop to an ATM).
author: Audrey L.

description: The guy behind the counter was awfully rude. I came to do some work but the immediately negative attitude had me go down to Four Barrel closeby.
author: Ed L.

description:
My friends and I aren't from SF and we were walking around for a long time so we sat down to take a break. Plugged in my phone to the wall and chatted for 5 minutes. A woman from behind the counter approaches us and asks us if we're going to order anything or if we're just here to charge our phones. She goes on and says that if we want to come in and charge our phones, we should at least come in and ask. She added that the shop was a business and they needed payment and didn't want to sit and wait for us to order. She walked away to wipe the tables surrounding us and didn't say another word.

Very, very unprofessional. We were checking out the menu, unsure of what to get and discussing which and what to get. Because of the rude encounter, we didn't order. We left to another shop across the street. Muddy customer service.
author: Arvin S.

description: I've been here a few times, similar experience each time. Lady at the front was extremely rude to myself and the other patrons, several of which tried to make lighthearted gestures or greetings. I asked for the wifi and was yelled at to "wait a second." Wifi ended up not even working which was part of the reason why i came by. Rude lady was there each time, being rude. Bagel sandwiches arent very good, but I loved the masala chai (spicy) which is what brings them from 1-2 stars.
author: K W.

description:
A second branch(?) of a similar location with the same name on 24th and Valencia

Walking in, the whole vibe is remarkably similar to the other Muddy Waters coffee shop. The furniture, the customers, and even the taste of the coffee is very similar. At first I thought the place looked small, but in fact half the store is behind the cash register area (you have to walk around it), and most of the customers are actually hiding out back.

The menu is basically identical to the other Muddy Waters place, and even written in the same style of chalk, with the same items and prices.
author: Henry L.

description: Really really rude short haired woman working here (might be the owner) who wouldn't let me wait for my friend to arrive before ordering. She had the worst attitude and basically told me to order something immediately or leave, despite the fact that I was waiting for someone. Won't ever be back here
author: LaMaruja M.

description:
I've been coming here regularly for the past 9 years because my son goes to school at Synergy, just down the street. I typically work from here maybe once a week. The WiFi is strong and stable. The staff is all wonderful (especially Ms. Hoda, but the owner is extremely nice too), the coffee is always perfect and they learned how I liked it by the 3rd time. The music tends towards World music with some jazz thrown in, which is a perfect mix for me (and it's not too loud, like in some coffee shops, so you can here yourself think, or have a conversation). They recently changed the bathroom access, and also put a mirror in there, so it's way more convenient now. 

The only downside at Muddy's is a non-controllable for them...they are in the edgy Mission, so sometimes people wander in who haven't bathed in awhile, or someone will be smoking pot outside the front door, which can waft in (I like to sit in one of the front window tables, so I get the full force of that). There's also a Google bus stop in front, so you get the fumes, noise and the crowded sidewalk, but that's pretty minor and mainly in the morning commute hours. Oh yes, there is free street parking on the adjacent streets, but only for 2 hours, then you have to move your car.

I've met some very interesting people here too (noted authors, creative types, local politicians). Although I am working and not looking for distractions, that can be an added benefit when I'm in a social mood.
author: Linda P.

description:
There is a photo of the barista posted above. The guy in the plaid shirt. 

Now, first of all, I can understand how someone working in this coffee shop would have a chip on their shoulder about arrogant disdainful tech people overrunning their neighborhood. But I am not one, and am holding on in SF by my fingernails. I don't look like someone who's threatening your livelihood or driving people out of your neighborhood, I don't dress like one, or stand like one, talk like one or walk like one. I'm not one. 

So----why this guy would stand there looking at me with his lip curling higher and higher, his brow furrowing deeper and deeper as I walked to the counter, I do not know. He stood there grimacing until I actually got to the counter. And then, when I was just about to order, he turned his back. And stood there. I don't know--I thought--maybe he's crying?! He looked so dour. But no, he lurched forward and put something in the microwave and stood in front of it. Then he made what looked to be a very terrible latte. 

A dude strolled in and said something to him, the barista said "hey man ya what's up?" and handed him a key - they spoke a bit. 

OK....now? Now will he...? No. He turns his back again. No "Hey, I'll be right with you" or "D'ya know what you want?"  or "Hold on a second." Goes and gets the item from the microwave, calls the person who ordered it, who seems a regular, they exchange a few furtive words. 

Ok...now?  Nope. Turns his back and stands there. "Excuse me." Turns around. I say "Hey, how're you doing?" Says nothing. Looks at me like I'm the chick who stepped on his ferret sometime back in the '90s. 

"Sigh. What can I get you?" "What kind of cakes are those?" "Chocolate." "Is it just chocolate?" "Yup." Turns his back. "But...there's another kind of cake. What is that." "Uhh. Raspberry." "Oh, like all vanilla but with like some kind of filling.....? or.....?" "Yeah."  "Sorry, can you turn it around so I can see it?" 

Looks like he wants to take a hatchet to my skull, like I had just demanded that he travel from one end of the cafe to the other without touching the floor using only monkey bars and the tables.  Turns the cake slightly around. "Ok, I'll have a slice of that,"  Walks away and fiddles with something. Then rings it up. 

"That'll be $6.95 "$7 for one piece of cake?" "No," he says, "It's SIX- NINETY-FIVE." "Well, I'm surprised---I've ordered cake here before. Where's the price listed?" He just sort of shifts on his hip, stands there, turns halfway to the side. Says nothing. I'm not exaggerating. Just stands there gazing into the middle distance.

I'm now pissed "Where's the price listed?" 

"Yeah. It's not" he says.

"Look, I've gotten cake here before--it's not 7 bucks." "Well this one is." And turned away. I left. 

Way beyond rude. Bizarre.
author: Swiss C.

description:
I agree with Heather J, this place is "full of characters." I was brought here by a co-worker who said this is the spot the recovering addicts all go to...so you know their coffee is strong. And she was right!
The bathroom is super sketchy, so know before you go =)
author: Cynthia B.

description:
I rarely patronize establishments in the Mission since its massive gentrification, but I had a meeting at the Women's Building last night. After my meeting, I decided to grab an americano before heading home on BART. I should've listened to my inner voice and walked right out when I asked the person at the counter if they had almond milk and he answered without even looking at me (he's pictured in another review with the plaid shirt). He proceeded to offer the worst customer service that I have received at a java spot. I'm not sure what his problem could be, but he certainly shouldn't take it out on customers. And, to top it off, the coffee was weak. I actually threw it out half full.

"Eek...!"
author: Felicia P.

description: Terrible place. The barista was rude, aggressive, and borderline psychotic. The bathroom was absolutely disgusting. And the coffee was foul. Avoid at all costs.
author: Tyler H.

description: I won't be coming back because of this rude barista dude. Asked for a manager or manager name and he said there is not one and wouldn't address me or look me in the eye. Too many rude things between this guy towards me and my friend. Worked in customer service forever and I'm an RN now as well, this is no way to treat people if you want their business. Any manager that wants details, contact me.
author: Will H.

description: Very rude staff. Asked to use the restroom and of course I was going to buy something but she was very rude about it. I go to use the restroom and it was disgusting they didn't even have toilet paper. I don't think someone should have to purchase something to use that bathroom. Then I go to buy a tea and I've never been here so I asked what their selection was and someone was behind me so I said he could go first and she was like I already got his order what do you want and proceeded to laugh. I will NEVER come back to this place. VERY RUDE!!!!
author: Gabrielle S.

description: I don't think I've ever experienced such rude and unprofessional behavior from a server. Also, muddy waters is right--that bathroom is disgusting.
author: Chelsea L.

description:
Chilling atmosphere and kind staff.
Brownies and coffee are perfect.
I would come here again for sure if I lived in SF
author: Natsuko H.

description:
So I was on a mission for coffee running late for work. I spotted this place with a park out front and quickly pulled over. 
The lady at the counter was nice and friendly. I ordered a Iced Vanilla Latte with Almond Milk. For some reason the Almond Milk said unsweetened  but was vanilla flavored. Oh well I'll try it anyway. I also got a slice of coffee cake. 
The Almond Milk Was not sweet at all so we added a little more vanilla flavor and it came out perfect.
Now to the main event. That Coffee Cake is the BEST I EVER HAD. It's so soft and not overly sweet. I will definitely be going back for another piece. Maybe on my first break from work. 
Overall a nice coffee shop I wouldn't mind going back to
author: Ayana K.

description: Should have looked at the reviews first. I just needed a caffeine fix before leaving the city. The Barista looked and was super cranky and unfriendly to everyone. He definitely did not look happy to be working. Don't go here
author: Kathleen P.

description:
The barista that a lot of people complain about, is actually a pretty cool dude. I hate when baristas make small talk. Just get me my coffee dude. One thing is being friendly, and a polite "How's it going?", I honestly, don't expect people to tell me how actually things are going. This dude gets it. 

Coffee is ok, but I really like that I can chill in the back, and the other people in there seem to mind their own business as it should be. If you like your privacy and unobtrusive patrons and servers, this is the place to be.
author: Albert C.

description: Nice place I wish if they have comfy seats to be able to bring my laptop and spend more hours.
author: Hind A.

description:
Muddy water is an iconic cafe I'm heart of mission.
Their coffee is great and very good.
Convenient for student as they have wifi and serve great coffee and teas
author: Mohammad Z.

description:
I only worked a half day but I still feel jet-lagged, twitchy and leaden after the grueling commute under the Bay, and I'm only part of the way home. 

Naturally, I buy another coffee. 

The Cafe Artist is, as far as I can tell, having a really good day. He rushes the line -- wiry hair flying about -- and demands a muffin. The barista chides him: "I'm trying to talk to someone." He's used to The Cafe Artist's antics. This unpretentious barista seemed genuinely concerned for me when he asked me how I was doing. I was about to answer 'good' or even 'great' when The Cafe Artist interrupted us. I wasn't about to complain of the middle class neck pain plaguing me, or my desire to jump off a building -- that would be ridiculous. Complaining of white collar cognitive dissonance and the insidious pains of sitting at a desk when the barista can barely afford to keep himself in shelter with what they must pay him. But he's alive! And possessed of the kind of nutty energy one acquires by daily encounters with chaotic people. This is the place to sit and watch the upper middle class hordes stepping around street people as they devour the Mission. The Cafe Artist must think so, or he wouldn't sit facing it. 

He tells me he's a documentary filmmaker. He's from Columbia. "The human rights violations in Columbia, that's what I film." Does he do commercial stuff? Sure he does. (He's a little vague about this.) We get to talking about Gabriel García Márquez, whom the Cafe Artist interviewed fifteen years ago. He recounts how Márquez struggled making the transition from Aracataca to Bogotá, how he had to pawn his typewriter, his experience of the coup -- nothing I don't already know from the autobiography.

"I'm interested in the creative process," The Cafe Artist tells me. Most people who talk of the creative process are applying for a grant or just prefer talking to the real thing. Skepticism piqued, I let it pass. By the time we get to Borges we're back on the same page, holding forth with help from enthusiastic hand gestures and big smiles, just like the cafe artists depicted in Márquez' autobiography. I tell him I've only read the master's minor works -- namely, Memory of My Melancholy Whores -- as is my habit. Has he read Enrique Vila Matas? Only a little. Our camaraderie shaken, I plod on anyway: "This crop of Spanish language writers who live in books, who write about writing, who create little Macondos of intertextuality: what's up with that?" "I know what you're getting at," he assures me. Neither of us invoke Cervantes at this crucial impasse. 

Just when it seems I've lost him he returns to Borges, professing his passion for the great ambassador of Hispano-English letters in broken English careening into mellifluous Spanish. I feel like I'm hallucinating, like I can understand everything he's saying despite not speaking Spanish because I know so well what he speaks of, like I'm really in a cafe in Bogotá in the '50s, on the brink of anarchy or bloodless revolution. Holy shit, this guy's enthusiastic! And he's not even crazy. (Only crazy people talk to me in San Francisco.) "You must write every day!" he implores me. I know, I know, but it's only Wednesday and I'm already burnt out!

A shoeless man weaves through traffic outside. I ask The Cafe Artist for the time. I'm supposed to be meeting my wife for a film. This is a good stopping point. We've spilled our passions, now it's back to pleasantries. The Cafe Artist has shit to do. "I'm meeting someone, too," he says, "some other guy." You can't blame him for thinking people (aside from French and Brazilian tourists) actually sit and converse here -- he's only lived in the city for four months.

All right, Mr. Cafe Artist. I'll be seeing you.
author: Dan S.

description:
Going to Muddy Waters was a terrible experience. 
First, the atmosphere is very cheap and creepy. Nothing feels cleans, it is almost always quite empty, and the food never looks fresh. 

The service is terrible. One Friday a co worker and I went in for a bagel. The service was rude to say the least. The woman serving us had such an attitude. We left and went to another cafe because of this, and because the interior was so dark, dirty, and dreary. 

Later that day, I decided to go back to muddy waters because 1) I was having a family emergency and needed an outlet so I could communicate with them. I thought muddy waters would have one available because they are so empty, and I also needed some quiet. 2) Watching  my friend eat her bagel put me in the mood for one. 

When I returned, I sat down, plugged in my computer and phone (to secure my seat and my outlet), checked my phone for family updates and was about to pull out my wallet and go to the counter. My friend was also meeting me there to grab lunch and coffee for herself, btw. But before I could do anything (I checked my watch: literally 1 minute after arriving to the shop), the woman behind the counter began shouting at me. She remained behind the counter the entire time, yelling across the room. She degraded me, calling ME disrespectful for coming into her store with another stores coffee (there was 1/4 liquid left in my cup) and food (I didn't have any food with me- I assume she thought I had some in a plastic bag I had with me that I had just put something I bought from a store inside). She kicked me out of the coffee shop even after I tried explaining that I was just here an hour ago and was back for more and that someone was meeting me, who I was waiting for. She didn't even give me the chance. I have never felt more embarrassed. 

It is a very common thing in SF to cafe hop and I don't understand why she thought that after being there for only a minute (again, I checked the time), I was simply not going to purchase anything (even though I had purchased something earlier that day??). There is just so much faulty logic on her half that I cannot begin to comprehend. 

I will never go back and tell my entire office to never work from there. 

Disgusting.
author: Meghan Y.

description:
I feel this place is still very San Francisco.  You can feel the community here.  I spent all day here and witnessed native Mission homegirls converse with a transperson, some old buddies meeting up for afternoon coffee, students coming in to do work, and they show sympathy toward the homeless who are just looking for a place to sit down and read.  

They also have ample space in the back with  many power outlets.  And the coffee is good.
author: Guadalupe G.

description: The staff is horrendous, I don't think I've ever been treated so bad at any other establishment in the city. I'm not a transplant, been in the area for over 16 years and it's a shame for a place to have this kind of treatment towards paying customers
author: Armando C.

description: Barista at Front desk was very aggressive and rude. My partner and I were looking for a coffee shop that stays open late enough to get some work done but we spent no more then 10 mins there, we arrived chose a seat near the front and tried to access the wifi. As we finished settling in we were approached by the barista and told us "If you kids want to hang out here you need to make a purchase and not waste our time" he then proceeded to stare at us from the counter. My partner and I left and headed to the 24hr Starbucks on California. We arrived at 9pm we usually go to Progressive Grounds on Bernal (closes at 8) or Muddy Waters on 24th (closes at 9) we will not be coming back to Muddy's on Valencia and 16th st.
author: Edgar M.

description: Solid cup of coffee and macaroon. It's open later than many other coffeeshops around the area. Wi Fi available. Pretty quiet and laid back atmosphere.
author: Annie L.

description: Stopped in to go to the bathroom and ended up buying a drink. The white mocha is delicious! Quiet relaxing atmosphere.
author: Mckenna P.

description:
I don't understand the low rating! Sassy barista and solid iced coffee? What's not to love!? It's also low key and not pretentious. I'm digging it. 
Lots of friends meeting up and a few people reading.
author: Tempie T.

description:
This place is probably not the best coffee house ever, but the baristas are so cool that they deserved the 4 stars! 
Cheap and nice place to work ;)
author: François A.

description:
- Locale Destination -
It's on Valencia St and 16th St in San Francisco.

It got an "Artistic" Mission vibe - tons of cool arts on the wall and chilled atmosphere. It's a bit rustic. The lady at the counter seemed to be French. She got a style and accent. They got a cafe au lait, not a cafe latte (It's French, you know!) ;p Free wi-fi and a few computers for your use!! Cash only ;( ATM inside!


- Gluttony Expedition - 
Cafe au lait : nice smooth milk foam. Small isn't so small! It's cheap !!


- Conqueror's Deduction - 
It's very cheap. Small size was good enough - at least for me. I'm not a coffee (caffein in general) drinker, but I think even Starbucks charges a lot more for just a coffee (to me). The cup was a very simple cheap paper cup, if you care. 
Everyone seemed to eat cakes... Next time.
author: Akiko I.

description:
Hahahhahahhaha is all I can think of when I think of this joint and I mean this with love.

First off, they make a legit chai latte. It leans towards the spicy side and tastes FANTASTIC w almond milk so I always come here for that.

The thing is though the people who come here are just one of a kind. Damn. I cannot even. I've met the craziest people, smartest people, conspiracy theorists, one guy who actually bring all his clothes and plus a desktop Into the wall jack and charges three phones at the same time.  Sometimes it can get sketchy since it's near 16th and this one time I got into an argument with an antisemitic dude who is always there but the owners shut him up right away.

It's a distinctly dope SF cafe so I recommend you go.
author: Mia F.

description:
I'm actually writing this review from Muddy Waters. If, during the few minutes it takes me to write this, I witness apathetic baristas, or if the wi-fi cuts out, I'll let you know. 

Most of the negative reviews seem to come from patrons upset by abrupt service. Sure, maybe there are some instances of employees being a little rude, or pre-occupied, but let's be real here - this is a neighborhood java joint, not the concierge desk at the Four Seasons. My expectation is that they take my money and make me coffee. About 85% of the time that's coupled with a "hey how are you?" or "how's it going?", and in all honesty there are times the barista jumps right to "what can I get you?" 

But is that really the end of the world guys? Is that really a reason to get in a huff, run to your laptop, and give them 1 star, because the employee didn't ask about your feelings? Gimme a break.

FYI the wi-fi didn't require a login, it's pretty fast, there are outlets by just about every table (even most starbucks can't offer that), and my white mocha is pretty damned tasty. 

If you're looking for coffee, and perhaps a place to chill and surf the net, this place is a nice option. Plenty of tables, fast service, it's open late, and very much that Mission SF aesthetic we all love.
author: Scott R.

description: The coffee was good... The service not that much ... The guy there, who had his picture posted , didn't  even bother to look at you when you talk to him. When I asked about the restroom, he simply said: "someone stole the key !!! "
author: Marwen B.

description: Tried working here for awhile with little success. It's a convenient spot, but like many cafes in SF, wifi is virtually non-existent. Odd drink selection of non-coffee drinks. Despite having key for restroom, the lack of any toilet paper and urine covering seat and floor had me walking out. I really wanted to like this place, but I won't be back.
author: Megan K.

description: This place is bomb. Five stars no problem. Convenient location, opposite of your new norm pretentious SF coffee spot, open super early and late, free wifi, AFFORDABLE great coffee (they have iced H2O decaf, who has that), nice interesting peeps, super nice staff, and paleo snacks? Sign me up, I'll be back in the morning!
author: Morgan H.

description:
Worst coffee shop ever! 

I went there in the afternoon while waiting for my friend to arrive, so I took out my MacBook. Not long after I sat down, maybe 5-10 minutes, the rude barista was in front of me and pressuring me to buy some coffee. I said sure, as soon as my friend is here. He didn't take more than 10 mins before, he came back once again to impolitely force me to purchase something. At this point, I was skeptical to stay in here any longer, let alone buy a coffee that according to the reviews is not worth buying. 

This bad barista looked like he was recently let out of jail. His whole demeanor seem to be aggressive, I'm not sure if he was having a bad day or what, but he should not have taken it out on the customers. I called my friend and advised her of the situation and left the coffee shop.

Overall, no one should support this business as long as they have incompetent rude people working there.
author: Ismael O.

description: De facto San Francisco coffee house. The coffee is wonderful, flavorful, strong & hot! Great variety of pastries & eats. Fell in love with the Granola Jack! Free wifi, clean rest rooms, space to recharge your devices. Love it!
author: Renan R.

description: RUDE BARISTA and IMPROPER CAPPUCCINOS ~ welcome to another episode of... How Does This Business Survive?? a cappuccino is equal parts espresso, milk & foam; more espresso does NOT mean less milk! and yes, just like all the other reviews say: the barista is RUDE. this was my 2nd visit and both experiences were identical
author: Loren B.

description:
This is legitimately my favorite place to grab coffee in the Mission. Most of the time, I feel way too lame to even grab a simple coffee in these shops. There's something about knowing your baristas that really seems to help you get good service in most of the Mission shops. 

Muddy Waters wasn't like that at all. I felt instantly welcomed even though I'm not their typical client. (The blazer and business suit tends to make me feel really out of place at times). I've had their iced coffee (done darn well) and their Mexican hot chocolate (holy cow yes please!!!) along with some of their baked goods. I've never had bad baked goods here, and I'm quite the muffin snob apparently! I hate that they don't accept cards, but most places in the Mission apparently don't. I still prefer Coffee to the People when in San Francisco, but there is no better place in the Mission to grab coffee. The friendly baristas make it worth it even if they don't accept cards. My only complaint is that the WIFI is pretty darn spotty. I've spent over an hour trying to get my laptop, ipad or phone to connect without any success.
author: Marilee Z.

description:
15.01.01         3rd visit

Food and drinks ----------- 3 1/2

Pro
  Solid service
  Good drinks
  Solid prices
  Good customers

Con 
  Abhorant bathroom
  Smelly guest eating outside food
author: S.K. Y.

description:
This is quickly becoming my favorite coffee in the Mission. After going to all style and no substance coffee shops like craftsmen and wolves and stable cafe I really appreciate a place that makes some great coffee and has some breakfast food. I usually get the iced coffee there, it is delicious. I've also had the white chocolate latte and americano, both really good. They have a great selection of foods, ranging from standard bagels to more exotic treats. The only downside, like many coffee shops in the area, cash only.

The service is great there, which is what puts this place ahead of so many other. The Mission is full of places with great food & drinks but they come with a mountain of attitude or a 20 minute wait while your baristas talk about how cool they are.
author: Raquel L.

description:
Zero stars for the African-American barista donning tats & a bad attitude wednesday night. 

We walked in...the place was packed with lap top campers. So we stepped up to order & while we're deciding, barista doesn't greet us b/c he's too busy playing on his phone, which I can overlook. *After* we ordered, he barked, "Espresso machine is closed. And we're closing in ten minutes." Dude didn't even try to hide his disdain. He was straight up irritated & rude. Fuck that. 

I'm glad we didn't spend any money in there that night. A business that allows an asshole like that to work for them doesn't deserve our money. I'm don't expect cheery service with a smile, but blatant rudeness to customers deserves a call out with a one-star review on yelp!
author: Fancypants X.

description: Terrible customer service !! Got our order wrong, very rude then refused to give his managers name !! Then cash only ??!! Really ? 2015 in San Francisco ... Get with the program!!  Too many other coffee shops worthy of our $$ will not be back here!
author: Tiffany W.

description: I miss Najeet ( I probably spelled that wrong). I hope she has a good vacation. I went in this morning and the girl at the counter didn't use gloves when she made my bagel after handling cash. I'll definitely be waiting for Najeet to come back before I come back.
author: Crystal C.

description:
I stopped by with some friends on a Saturday afternoon to pick up some food and coffee. The  guy working here was really weird. I couldn't figure out if he was high or if he was genuinely that much of a dick. He made some really offensive comments about my friends ethnicity and appearance that were really offensive and made me really uncomfortable. 

Judging by the reviews below I think he gets some sort of weird kick out of it. It's really disappointing as this place could be a great hang out. All we did was walk in and before we even opened our mouths to ask for what we would like, he started being agro and offensive.
I will not be buying coffee from racists so I shan't be back.
author: Cat D.

description:
Crap coffee and horrible customer service.

I walked in and found the cashier sitting on the floor behind the cash register, busily texting/facebooking/instagramming on her phone. Normally this kind of stuff doesn't bother me, but that fact that it took her a good minute to even get up to greet me really rubbed me the wrong way. She was hard to hear and clearly annoyed that I would do something so atrocious as interrupting her social media break.

Anyway, I ordered an iced coffee just happy to be over with interacting with her. That is, until I realized I needed the restroom...

And here's the thing about the restroom: it has some rather peculiar signage instructing you to knock on the door and wait for a buzz.. Considering there were two people in front of me, still knocking, and still waiting for a buzz, I walked over to the cashier and asked if there was anyone in the restroom.

She replied "I dunno why don't you check?" Seriously, all she was missing was two snaps and a circle. 

I'm pretty sure the incessant knocking from the other two folks was suffice enough "checking" for me to go up to her. I mean, did she really think that that wasn't the first thing I did? (Bathroom magically buzzed open after that.)
author: Valerie C.

description:
Full of characters, and many of them smell quite bad.

But, the baristas are saints! Coffee is a little bit better than 7-11.
author: L. J.

description:
I had had the worst luck with wifi at the start of the morning. Found a juice bar and got  a smoothie. On the windows of the place it clearly stated they had wifi for customers. I got my smoothie (which was delicious) and proceeded to pull out everything I wanted to work on that morning. I tried to get onto the network (with the password the employee provided) and it said it couldn't connect. I mentioned this to one of the two employees working and she said, sorry. I figure the router needed to be reset or something, but I am not sure she know where that was or what to do. 

So, I walked around looking for the next best option. I stumbled upon Muddy Waters heading towards the area where I would be having lunch later. I walked in and saw they had some vegan options. I asked if they had wifi, and they did.

I got an onion bagel with hummus and topped with tomatoes and 3 dolmas. An almost perfect breakfast if you ask me. The wifi worked great and I was able to get a good amount done. I would go back to this place, if even just to have a bagel and dolmas again.

Yum!
author: Deanna C.

description: This is a true local Mission coffee shop, unlike the Four Barrel down the block. It is for those who are okay with a little bit of an edge. Don't come here if you're looking for a fancy Marina style cafe.
author: Nick L.

description:
I'm thoroughly unimpressed.

The iced coffee was decent. Strong, which is good with iced coffee, and the fixings were readily available (simple syrup, cream, etc). The muffin was a little dry, but decent.

The one star is for the barista, an African-American guy who seemed disinterested at best. I was just sort of standing in front of the display with all of the different bottled drinks and looking over the menu because I hadn't been there before, and there were a few people doing the same. He snippily announced, "Whenever anyone's ready, just give me your order." He wasn't friendly, he wasn't nice, he wasn't even cordial.

The place is also a little bit of a mess. Maybe it's just poor design choice, but the plywood wall near the entrance and the beat-up look of the place just don't make it particularly welcoming.

In short: Not going back. There are tons of other coffee shops that have better service, look nicer, and actually seem like they want to be open for business in a few months' time.
author: Adam K.

description: Good coffee house in the mission district.  Pluses- outlets at every table to charge your gadgets, free wi-fi, coffee, drinks, kid's table and toys to keep them occupied, and baked goods. It's a work friendly lace, meaning it's good for people who want to come in and sit down with a coffee and food and work online. Minuses - decor. It's dated and somewhat unattractive.
author: Ralph R.

description:
I've stopped in here a couple of times. It's a great place to meet up with friends and have a nice chat. There's seating in the back and if you need to use internet, you can also use the internet here. The macaroon is pretty good and so is the chai. I'm not sure if I want foam, so I'll ask for no foam next time. The prices are probably what you'd pay at a normal chain.

Be aware, the benches in the back are not suitable for sitting there for a long period of time.
author: Amy J.

description:
I've definitely experienced better. Came to this cafe to do work and asked about wifi - there was a sign with the wifi network name and password, but I tried that and it didn't work. The employee said I was the only one who was having trouble so it must be my computer - but after asking a few customers, it seemed like no one's internet was working. The employee just yelled and said it's my fault.

I left. If you want to do work here on your computer and use the wifi, don't come here.
author: Ena Y.

description:
First time, last time. If the owners check the time stamp on this thing, your guy behind the counter was doing nothing and still completely forgot that I ordered a hot chocolate. There were four other customers in the entire place, mine was the only active order, and no one else ordered after me for the rest of the night. Meaning, the employee wasn't juggling orders--there was only one. The request for the single (1) pastry in addition to the beverage might have been overwhelming, but I think other coffee houses can handle it. Pathetic. No apologies, no words, no anything. When I asked for my drink over ten minutes later, he all but threw it at me. When I talked to him after I finished some work, another apparent employee who had been working on his laptop stepped in. In response to my request that someone SIMPLY ACKNOWLEDGE that the guy forgot my drink for over ten minutes, I was told "This isn't a fancy coffee house. You want that, you go somewhere else. It's the Mission. It's how we roll." 

How we roll?!? Their business plan: just take the customers' money. When they ask for what they paid for, treat them horribly (I'd curse, but don't want to get this review removed), and grudgingly throw their order at them while calling them elitist scum. 

Great plan, guys.
author: Mark F.

description: Decent coffee, barista remembers my usual, great seating. A little noisy at times and the bathroom's a bit odd, but I appreciate this spot. Chances are you won't feel like a seat hog at one of the Muddy's if you need to work on a laptop for a while.
author: Jae R.

description:
A typical Saturday in the Mission calls for some munchies and a cup of coffee to wash it down. I'm not a fan of coffee, but one day I had an intense craving for Mexican hot chocolate. My friends and I randomly walked into the first coffee shop we spotted and to my surprise, my wishes immediately came true. 

MEXICAN ALMOND HOT CHOCOLATE. This place took my craving to a whole new level with the almond. It's pleasantly aromatic and tastes like heaven. The lady behind the counter outdid herself.

Speaking of the lady, she was fantastic. Open-hearted, friendly, and welcoming. Although we were 3 out of hundreds of customers she probably had that day, she still made us feel special. 

A great place to grab a quick beverage. Plenty of room to sit down in a nicely decorated environment.
author: Dmitriy S.

description:
Not the best coffee or best of anything for that matter. Things are often stales, etc. Though, Ive been coming here for 20 years and its the same people working here. Dude behind the counter still does not say hello, even after 20 years. The place has not changed a bit. Theres a lot to be said for that. 

Its like visiting grandmas house. Coffee houses like they were in the 90s.
author: H K.

description:
Lackluster coffee, atrocious service. 

Normally I give SF the benefit of the doubt, who really wants to be brewing coffee on a lovely afternoon when there are clearly other fun things to be doing? So I get it - good weather can bring out the sour attitude of anyone behind the counter.

But dude. This shop is embarrassing. Interacting with the barista was like talking to a sarcastic boulder. I'm talking to you, Leon.

There's better coffee and service a few minutes away. Do yourself a favor and avoid this place.
author: Russell W.

description: Basic easy going place near the Bart. Great prices, strong $2 coffee, friendly owner and free WiFi. Have the dark chocolate biscotti!!!!
author: Nik Y.

description:
No nonsense coffee shop, a nice change from all the hipster cafès in the area.
The food is good the coffee is great and they stay open late.
author: Fiachra O.

description:
CASH ONLY! (they have an ATM)

I've always gotten great service here. I used to work right down the street and was a frequent customer. (I still come back) The barista Najad is really nice and has a great sense of humor while manning (or person'ing) the counter by herself. 

Their coffee is decent. (Never have any complaints)

I really like their salmon bagel. It's a must try if you like that sort of thing. You can modify and add extras to your liking, which is nice.

I do wish they would do something about the plywood posting board that covers the complete left side wall of the entrance. (Maybe paint it or turn it into art) I think it would add a but more flavor to the place, instead of making it look like unfinished handy work. 

However, on the other side of the wall there is local art work hanging that gives a nice sense of community artistic support. 

The back area is a great place to buckle down and chat, or call your office away from...your office. 

I really love this place and I enjoy doing business with Najad. The only huge critique that I have is that they need a bit of an artistic makeover with the left side of the entrance. They could possibly update the sign painted on the front and window. I really think this place deserves it.
author: Mike G.

description: May be my favorite coffee place in San Francisco.  Coffee is good.  Counter people are gruff but efficient and generally friendly beneath-it-all.  Customers are an eclectic mix.  And yes, bathroom is disgusting.
author: Mike B.

description:
*1.5 stars*

Coffee was undrinkable, I actually threw it out, and the bathroom was filthy. The space itself is ok and was relatively full of people so it may have been a bad brew or just a bad day, which is why I'm giving this place two stars instead of one. That being said, I doubt I'll ever go back.
author: Michael A.

description: Staff are friendly and the echinacea tea that was suggested was really good considering I was sick. Downside was the shoddy Internet, it was slightly dirty and some of people there - couple of friendly homeless people  which was OK but their baggage, aroma and constant sneezing/coughing was a turn off. Only stayed there for 30 minutes when I was trying to spend 2-3 hours there to focus and get work done. Again I was sick and wasn't trying to get any sicker. Service and staff were cool but I'll probably check other coffeeshops next time.
author: Carl N.

description:
This place would be ideal for doing work - good size tables, lots of plugs and seating, open late - except the internet connection was pretty terrible when I went. Admittedly, I'm one of those people who goes to coffee shops primarily for the wifi, so that was a pretty big bummer.
The latte was pretty good, the food looked tasty, and the service was very friendly. Just get consistent internet and I will absolutely give this place consistent business.
author: Kelly M.

description: Their terrible food is only matched by their terrible service. I just ordered and coffee and bagel and she acted like it was offensive for me to have disturbed her.
author: Chelsea M.

description: Reliable coffee house for work, lots of power plugs, cash only though.
author: Grzegorz J.

description: The people who stop in here are pretty weird. One guy walked across the room and stood there in the middle of the empty space and just stared at me for about 10 seconds. He then waived at me and proceeded to walk back across the room to sit down. ??? Lol. The barista was nice. He seemed confused that I wanted my cappuccino iced, with foam. I can't drink it any other way! It was a great cup of Capp, I must admit. Also, they have all of these interesting vegan and gluten free food options. Just watch your step on the way out. I almost ate it this morning. Cool place. Will return.
author: Stephanie D.

description: manny is very cool. He does a great job as a barista. this is the only coffee shop in the mission that I know of that is open late every night has lots of space outlets.
author: Maria C.

description: I like the mocha and cookies. Usually a fast place to grab a coffee on my way to work.
author: Bill H.

description: I work near 16th and Valencia, so Muddy's is just a given when it comes to my morning coffee, or afternoon coffee, or any particular break in the day that calls for a little liquid inspiration. Fair prices, and a weird artsy bohemian atmosphere that seems to be so hard to find these days. This place has staff that's consistent and super chill. Always down for some Muddy's in my life. Sometimes they close before the posted closing time, which makes me bitter...but hey that's kinda how I like my coffee too, so I can't really hate on it.
author: Scott M.

description: Used this coffee shop while waiting to meet a friend at 16th and mission BART station. It's an inexpensive coffee shop if you want to spend 15-30mins. The shop however smells, I saw a bunch of people working here, I tried to but the place is noisy.
author: Suyog D.

description:
A reliable joint to visit.

It's a bit expensive, cash only IIRC, and the bathroom situation is annoying at best (I still can't figure out how it works after a 5 hour Scrabble session there with a visiting buddy).

Convenient location to BART, and a good amount of seating. It's a reliable place.
author: Conrad B.

description: The almond milk latte was nothing special. The milk was foamed too much! Surly barista, uninviting atmosphere, but I'm grateful for the caffeine.
author: Anna K.

description:
I usually never say this, especially about a neighborhood cafe in SF, which are a dime a dozen, but. . .

I WANT TO LIVE HERE.

As a writer who spends an unreasonable amount of time in cafes, scoping out cafes, reading about cafes, and writing reviews about cafes -- I am picky. Less about the coffee itself and more about atmosphere (although, if the Barista can only recommend I get an iced coffee when I ask for a suggestion, and then said iced coffee tastes like dirt water... I will shun you. I'm talking to you, Barefoot in Santa Clara.)

For me, the ideal cafe has plenty of seating, free WiFi & wall outlets, friendly baristas, good coffee, music/art presence, and attracts people from all different lifestyles (better for people watching :) )

Muddy Waters delivers.  From the moment I stepped in and saw a man wearing a suit and fedora, accompanied by a Virgin Mary tie, at a table he had decorated with gypsy scarves, miniature statues, and other obscenely random trinkets for sale. . . I knew that we would get along. 

First off - HUGE space for a SF cafe! They have two rooms that felt spacious, despite being filled with tables. A friendly Baristo (who is only friendly in the kind of way that you can tell he's genuinely nice) gave me my latte -- strong and delicious -- and smooth blues music lulled me in the background as I sat on a bench against the wall, enjoying their free WiFi and ambiance provided by the interesting patrons. Perfecto. I appreciated the balanced cleanliness of the place - it didn't smell like bleach, but there wasn't an array of sticky stuff spread around, either.  I was seriously tempted to sneak in a sleeping bag and refuse to leave. If the let some crazy man sell things off a table, I doubt they would flinch at a 22-year-old girl sleeping there. ;)

All in all, a success. I tip my hat to you, Muddy Waters -- in life and, in death, in the form of a coffee shop.  :-) (minus one star for cash only+no comfy chairs)
author: Anna F.

description:
In the face of $5 cups of single origin coffee, $2500 rents for 1 bedroom apartments and the every day presence of Town Cars blocking the disabled parking spots I have to field 5 stars to my favorite neighborhood holdout--Muddy Waters!

The ONLY Place that is open past 8pm. Come here and join the remaining artists, workers, script writers and poets...I hope we can sustain this cafe for the people as the rest of the City is bleached and painted gentrifier green.

ps: I get the tea ..coffee is NY Old school style before that city also embraced the $5 cup.
author: shanestar h.

description:
I'm giving this place 1 star (first of all because I can't give it anything less) but because I've also worked at a café and was impressed with the two drinks we got. 

Upon arriving to this place (yesterday), my friends and I were rudely greeted with the barista's uncomfortable sarcasm and awkward attitude. We ordered, paid, sat down, and waited. After thirty minutes, my friend finally decides to walk up to the barista to see where his drink was.  The barista rudely replies that he only had two hands but was going to make it in a moment. (It was very slow at the café, so waiting 30 minutes for a drink was an unreasonable amount of time). The entire time that we were at the café (from about 15:15 until 16:00) there was a lady (who did not work there but was friends with the barista) standing in front of the register, monitoring the café and keeping the barista company (which is partly why the barista was distracted and negligent of his job). My friend waits in front of the espresso machine until he gets his drink (a cappuccino without the shot of espresso, so just steamed milk). When he notices that there is no caffeine in his cappuccino, he asks for the barista to prepare him the drink he had ordered, and continues waiting. The barista's friend comes up to my friend and begins confronting him, telling him that he had been rude  to "her friend", the barista, and had no right to demand for another drink. The barista does not intervene, but my friend ignores the lady and keeps waiting for the drink. He finally gets the cappuccino (which actually looks good), and sits down to drink it. The lady, in the meantime, reaches over the espresso machine, and grabs the towel that the barista uses to clean the nozzle to steam milk, and she wipes her own elbow with it. UNSANITARY. The lady continues yelling at my friend across the café and is now looking at each one of us at the table. We are confused and try to ignore the whole situation, but she continues yelling at us even louder and the barista (her friend) just lets her continue. At this point, everyone at the café has now become involved with the situation and the lady comes over to our table and demands that we "settle things outside." In order to avoid this embarrassing situation from getting more out of control, we walk out and leave the drinks that we had been waiting for unfinished on the table. The lady follows us outside and continues yelling and insulting us. At one point, she walks up to another one of my friends and threatens to physically hurt her. We try talking sense into her and ask her to leave us alone, but she continues following and yelling at us, claiming that we had been rude to her friend and blaming us for San Francisco's decline (irrelevant). She is escorting us to Bart station on 16th and Mission when she makes a call to "some of her friends" who are expecting us at the Bart station. She is narrating our every move to her friends over the phone and gives a detailed description of how we look like, and that's when we decided to head back to Valencia street and seek help at the police station. 

I do not understand how the man behind the espresso machine ever got a job working here. He was truly inefficient, rude, and provided horrible service. He also should not have his troubled friends hanging out with him and causing trouble with the customers who are the ones paying his check. You can see a picture of the barista on a yelp review that someone else who visited this café on March 8 posted. Avoid going to this place if that man is working there.
author: Arnaud L.

description: Free Wifi that's it. No bagels left at 1:00 ended up getting a beef and cheese piroshki that tasted sour. I just hope I don't get sick. Oh the lady working here is nice, extra star for her.
author: Karen T.

description: The Mission has changed, but Muddy's has stayed delightfully disreputable. I hope it stays that way forever.
author: Tim C.

description: Terrible lighting and art (I had to turn around and not face it) but it's open when you need a nighttime cup of tea. Unpretentious and that counts for something in the mission these days.
author: Arlene D.

description:
I've been coming here for a little while now and I've gotten used to the long wait in the morning because they only have 1 person working per shift and it's not very organized. I've decided that going to Muddy Waters means you can't be in a rush to be somewhere. It's right by my apartment and on my way to work, so it's mostly a convenience that I go here instead of the goods/ service.

This morning really bummed me out, though. I've ordered my lattes with Najid (horrible spelling, my bad) plenty of times: hazelnut latte with just a little bit of hazelnut. I got my latte and all I taste is syrup - she put in waaaaay too much, after I've consistently ordered with "just a little bit". I ask her if she wouldn't mind re-making it when I tell her why. She remakes it, and it tastes the exact same.

By this point, I'm already running late for work and I ask her for a refund. And here is where she decides to argue with me. I tell her it tastes the exact same way, that I saw her put in a ton of syrup, and she just argues "no, I put in less syrup!". I'm clearly not getting a refund for a nasty latte, so I tell her to just forget it and throw it away. Call me crazy, but I just like a little bit of flavor added to my coffee, not the other way around.

I don't think I'll be coming back. If you're going to argue with a regular customer (or any customer, really) about the poor quality of your goods, then you won't get any more business from them.
author: Eilene G.

description: Iced coffee was okay and wheat Bagel was good. They don't take cards and the restroom doesn't lock
author: Misty P.

description: good service can stay here and get a lot of work done, wifi doesnt allways work right is the only issue has nice bathroom lots of homeless tweakers are paying customers here and hang out all day
author: Leigh G.

description:
I'll admit, the main reason I gave this place 4 stars instead of 3 is because they are open until 11pm. It's pretty hard to find a cafe open past 9, and Muddy Waters' late hours are why I keep coming here.

This location is not quite as nice on the inside as the 24th & Valencia one, but the rest is the same: alright coffee, drab atmosphere, WiFi is very unreliable. But they have electric outlets available. It's a good place to come when you need to get work on your laptop done. And it's really close to BART.
author: Al S.

description:
What a nasty female aggressive barista with glasses! Don't know her name - didn't want to know ... 

Her Attitude was just plain disgusting! Thank goodness she was bigger than me ... I was afraid she might punch me in the nose if I asked for my money back for the small (tiny) cup of coffee i purchased ... 

CHANGE The attitude - you're scaring the customers!
author: Sefo S.

description:
Decent iced soy latte. Almond milk is available as well, for non-dairy customers. Tasty-looking desserts.

My inattentive server was on the phone the whole time.
author: Brett N.

description:
I come here a lot.
