Cheap coffee, bagels, HUGE SLICES OF CAKE, really close to BART (so I can hop right off on my way back from class), lots of seating, lots of outlets (so, so important), and super close to burritos (MOST IMPORTANT)

The lady behind the counter is sooo sweet and they've always got a really interesting mix of songs playing. 

Def one of my most frequented study spots in the city.
author: Lalitha K.

description: Go somewhere else for coffee. They don't know how to make lattes here.  Ours were flat and cold. I had to have them put in the microwave to be drinkable!
author: Edwin O.

description: The coffee here fits the name of the place. It tasted like hot fertilizer water. If you're Swamp Thing, then this is your cup of mud. I waited for it to cool off so I could chug it and almost threw up. I will be back tomorrow.
author: mother b.

description:
Was in here a couple of weeks ago, randomly stopped by with a friend. I live in the Richmond and had to use my computer for about an hour. Wifi is good. Coffee was strong and good. The ice tea was amazing- i think it had orange blossom or something other magic. 

The highlight, however, has to be the people watching. Between the guy making puppets, the guy making coasters, all the Mission hipsters, and the peeps behind the counter...It was entertaining- although my friend and I were both painfully aware of how unhip we felt that day. :) Like this place and would return.
author: Bing B.

description:
Dingy little spot but great for coffee, bagels and a space to do work. 

They have plenty of table and the ones by the wall ALL have outlets. I'd definitely come here over starbucks. The music is good here as well. The wifi is free (called Muddys). 

Seemed like  friendly crowd and right on valencia close to plenty of other places if you decide to move around. 

I'm sitting here writing a grant that is due tomorrow and I"m glad that I chose this place. I will definitely be coming back.
author: Carlos A.

description: I'm a big fan on their coffee, the friendliness of the baristas and their overall service. However, the place smells horribly, and I try to remember to not smell anything while I'm there.
author: Joel V.

description: I used to be sort of putout by the surliness of the barista, but now I think it adds to the character of the place.
author: Kevin B.

description: Come here often on Saturdays & Sundays when ive got places to be near by. The coffee is quite nice, condiment bar is nothing special if not lacking abit, but the seating, outlets, bathroom, & privacy in the back maje up for what I would have given just 3 stars. Also I prefer this location to the one on 24th street. Its a nice little break away between all the shops on Valencia ti warm up or cool off  :)
author: Julian I.

description:
Occasionally, all the planets align. It just so happens that the Summit is closed for a private event or they've closed early cause it's a Sunday, and then 10:30pm rolls around, and there's just no respectable free wi-fi to be found in a 5-block radius.

Muddy's to the rescue. 

Sure, you need to brave the homeless people that seem to congregate by the horde, and sure, the barista is pissed off cause he's been dealing with homeless people all day and is probably the biggest douchebag you've ever met, and SURE, the bathroom doesn't actually have a lock.

But they've got wi-fi. And sometimes, that's all that matters.
author: Andrew V.

description:
I really like this place. There will be a line to the door at a certain coffee shop down the street by 15th early in the weekday morning while this place has little or no line. I think the coffee is not quite as good as places that have blue bottle, but it's not bad -- and it's cheaper. I'm still giving it 5 stars because it has so many good qualities that beat other places.

They have tons of seating (and it isn't pretentious).

It's also a very convenient location, since it is very close to the 16th BART station. And, of course, there is one near the 24th station too.

The woman normally at the cash register is incredibly nice and friendly. The other people there are fine too.
author: Melissa M.

description:
I can tell that the pseudo intellectuals, writers that come to SF will love this place "atmosphere".. and i do agree, it's a very nice place to seat and read, i love the art, specially the cool stuff in the restrooms... The problem is that this is not art gallery, and the coffee is mediocre at best, and the service is indifferent. I know they don't follow big corporations standards, but small business are also supposed to care about their service and quality.. 
I'll give it another try and see if i have a barista that likes her job a bit more..
author: Daniel D.

description: One of the last original San Francisco coffee spots left, located in the Mission. While the Mission is getting gentrified by Yuppies and Hipsters, this place is still authentic and depicts San Francisco's culture. My dad has been coming here for over 25 years.
author: Rico H.

description: Went in a while back (definitely not my first time) on a weekend morning. Wasn't super crowded, plenty of other tables around. The barista walked over to me after five minutes of getting myself situated at a table - which is my usual routine - to tell me to either buy something or leave and was incredibly unfriendly and short with me. I had planned on staying for a while and getting a bagel or something to eat but instead got a bottle of water and stayed only five more minutes. Not going back again. Maybe they're going through hard times, but being disrespectful to customers is not the way to save a business.
author: Mauro S.

description:
Fast only because no one is there. Coffee is meh. Pastry selection is weak. Service is mixed.

If I am desperate for a quick coffee, I may be back. But likely not.
author: Ben V.

description: Great atmosphere. Quick, friendly service. Coffee ain't so great. Pretty much the exact opposite of four barrel coffee
author: Jake B.

description: I come because this place is never crowded and there's free wifi and electrical outlets everywhere. You have your basic coffee house options and I have no complaints. Service is friendly but they are usually on the phone, I don't mind though because they can multitask and I don't really need to have a conversation when I'm just getting the $2.00 iced coffee so I don't feel guilty about using your wifi and electricity for the afternoon.
author: Matthew C.

description: Had to meet someone here for a business meeting. I was hoping I really liked the place so I could go back there again but unfortunately the service was borderline rude. The ladies who were working behind the counter were too involved in their conversation to greet me and I had to say "excuse me" to get their attention even though they were two feet from me. No thank you, no manners. I will not be back nor will my friend. I like to support the smaller, family owned coffee shops but I will take my money elsewhere.
author: Nicole O.

description: Whenever I get off at 16th street bart and want some coffee I swing by this place. The boss behind the counter is a really funny lady that never fails to make me laugh after one of her jokes. There's some cool artwork on the walls as well. She generally plays a blend of foreign music and the clientele that hang out here are generally reading, talking with friends or finishing some projects for school and work. Not to mention, the coffee is pretty good too.
author: Maximilian R.

description:
Chimin' in here  on the "less than great" train.  As others have said, this place has such potential, and it looks as though they tried to live up to that recently, having replaced the chairs and tables with sturdier fare.  

But...

the dude who works most evenings is just insufferable. He ooses disdain for customers, hardly uttering a word or exhibiting any expression.  If he's that unhappy he oughta get another gig.

the wifi sucks. it often doesn't  work, and when it does it's slower than molasses in January.

the clientele often appears to consist of RP Mc Murphy and his compatriots.  Seriously, people talking to themselves, people sitting writing senseless epistles on newspapers.  

the bathroom is *gross*.

It's in my 'hood, but I'm done.
author: Unemployed D.

description: The Coffee is ok and they open til late, but that's all the stars they'll get. The guy who worked at the register(dark hair, glasses) is a total douche, he had no problem showing how much he didn't give a shit about his customers and smiling was too much of a task for him, and the tip jar (empty)reflected his bad attitude!
author: Ladywolf M.

description:
This place is a dump and crack central social club. 

The energy is way dodgy, and the characters came out of Martin Landau Dracula's movies. 

The the other location on valencia and 24th aint much better.


It need an entire makeover and a demographic cleanup.
author: Chuck N.

description:
Hole in the wall describes this place quite well. Baristas seemed a little cold, not enough power outlets, bla bla bla. There was an eclectic group of people, and a playful terrier playing with me while I was walking to the counter - maybe he smelled cat on my beloved lululemon hoodie that seems to tell hipsters to keep 25 feet away from me or it's a dog's way of saying hi? I dunno.

There are other places in the Mission, but hey I like places like than their corporate brethren.
author: Navi T.

description: Nice people here, but now that I've discovered Four Barrel is down the street, the magnetic tractor beam of their coffee will draw me in the opposite direction of MW when I leave the office.
author: Emily M.

description: Want a quiet cup of coffee with a sweet?  Then, DO NOT GO TO MUDDY WATERS! Staff today took the position that the street people entering were preferred over real paying customers.  And complaints to management met with not so much as a nod.  Needless to say, I'll be taking my custom to establishments where it's appreciated.  NOT HERE!
author: David H.

description: The place is good but except their coffee there is nothing great ....I tried their spinach and cheese FILO pastry and it was horrible.... And I do not know why they only deal in cash that's little strange ..
author: Manish T.

description: I'm visiting SF from LA and happened upon this coffee shop in The Mission.  It's 10am.  There's a guy here in full-on Marilyn Manson make up.  YES!!  I don't know if this is because I'm in The Mission or because it's THIS coffee shop but I'm gonna go ahead and give Muddy Waters the credit.  Service was fast, coffee is good, free wifi, good music, and it would get 5 stars if they served artificial sweeteners.  All you get is brown sugar or simple syrup and I like my coffee chemical-y.
author: Sharon H.

description: I occasionally go to Muddy Waters for a latte and sometimes work there.  I love the coffee and lattes there.  I am occasionally annoyed at the preponderance of homeless people asking for money.  But, I guess thats part of living in a big city.  I do wish the people working there would be more willing to kick people out if they are bothering paying customers.
author: Floyd F.

description:
Ehhhh. . . . . . 

Open late which is cool... that aside.... 

.. Small pastries that you can tell have been sitting out all day are $2.50 whereas my personal fav. coffee shop in Alameda lowers the price to $1 (for larger ones) after 3pm & is also open late.. 

.. Service was meh.. 

.. Bathroom was ranky dank. Nasty. Yucky. No bueno..

.. Their wifi happened to not be working (and I get the impression it usually isn't)... 

On pretty much the only other positive note I can think of, the mocha I got was pretty good & a reasonable size for the size small portion. 

Yeah... I'll pass next time. :(
author: Kai S.

description: Actually, I don't think the prices are fair. They charge $2.50 for a 16oz iced tea - no refills. Starbucks charges $3 for a 30oz iced tea, with $0.50 refills. AND, if you use the rewards card, UNLIMITED FREE REFILLS. I save money by going to Starbucks. (I know - I surprised myself!) I like the tea better (green tea instead of black), and the Internet is at least 5x faster (50mbps). I get the whole "support your local businesses", but honestly, spending $10 (4x16) vs. $3(2x31 - one free) for a half gallon of iced tea is a no brainer.
author: Lake Y.

description:
What can I say except this place rules... with all the over priced coffee houses popping up in the neighborhood it's nice to have a haven of sanity.

The staff is friendly, the prices are fair and the free wi-fi is simply icing the cake!
author: Rebecca S.

description:
Not a cozy-little-nook high-design coffeeshop. Too dirty for the hipsters, too open for the agoraphobics. On the other hand, free easy WiFi, coffee that's either pretty good or a little burnt depending on the time of day, giant cookies, and it's easy to find a table. And the benches are really comfortable; after a few zillion people have sat on the wood, it's nice and worn.

It actually feels sort of like a bar feels during the day. A little gritty, but comfy and well-worn.
author: E.O. S.

description: Well, I am a coffe lover who admires coffe with a bite. Muddy Waters on 16th street has a vast array of customers from the friendly Mission artists to the techies, to the rag-muffins that makes San Francisco such a great city. My fav barista there is Joel, and Najat is super cool too. I like Muddy's because they mean business when it comes to getting your coffe quick, a most for coffee freaks like me. They are also open later than most coffee houses, a big plus for nite owls like me.
author: Monica S.

description:
I ate a chocolate-dipped macaroon here that transcended space and time.

Okay, maybe I'm exaggerating. 

But it was really really really really really good. 

Otherwise useful: solid coffee, well-rounded menu of the sweet and savory, free wifi, plenty of outlets, cool artwork. 

(Chocolate-dipped macaroon!)
author: Anna G.

description:
Muddy's was the first coffee shop I ever went to in San Francisco almost 14 years ago, and coming from points east, and in a pre-Starbuck era, I was floored by how strong the coffee was. FLOORED. 

I still use Muddy's coffee as the yardstick by which to measure all others. Brewed fresh frequently, using solid-quality beans, by people who love coffee.  Strong and tasty. And Muddy's is also a yardstick for coffee shops. All kinds of people hang out here, and I mean ALL kinds, including both people who talk to themselves because they're crazy and people who talk to themselves because they're wearing Bluetooth implants. 

It's unpretentious, with good light and multiple tables and chairs that are just the right height for reading and writing. They have all the beverages. They have all the cafe snacks. They have the only yummy vegan cookies in existence. And their flyer wall is a pretty good way to get the Zeitgeist of SF.

Also, Joel, the angry young man with excellent taste in music who works several nights a week, has worked here longer even than that. He will make you the *BEST* mocha in SF. Hands down. People who don't drink mochas, don't get mochas, and can't make them, so they can be hit or miss in this town. But Joel's mochas (and Americanos) FTW. If he seems grumpy to you, it is because he has to handle the hassle of the madding crowds.

I'm always amused by people who go to the Mission for coffee and say, "ew, gross, it's got character." I suppose that shows my "age," in terms of believing I live in the pre-dot-com Mission instead of the Tablecloth Mission. If you don't want to be hassled by street people on 16th and Valencia, don't hang out on 16th and Valencia. They've been on that corner probably longer than Joel.

Regarding the bathroom, Muddy's has recently installed a brand-new toilet and one of those most excellent high-powered Xcelerator hand dryers, and it's generally cleaner, although as with most coffee shops, YMMV. Your attitude toward bathroom graffiti, I cannot help you with. You are in fact in the Mission.

(My personal coffeeshop checklist. Doesn't really impact the score.)
Outside seating? Yes, four seats.
Bathroom OK? YMMV
Nutmeg? Yes.
Splenda? Yes.
author: Tarin T.

description:
Pros: it's open late. lots of outlets for laptops. most people here are just trying to study so it's not too loud.

Cons: wi-fi is ad based and VERY slow. The neighborhood is very sketchy. That can sometimes be a good thing bringing a "gritty" feeling to the shop. But, mostly, it is annoying.

Overall: an okay place to get some studying done.
author: Sirish M.

description: Nothing fancy this place is what it is. It's one of the few coffee places open relatively late in the area and it serves ... you guessed it coffee. Their beans don't come from some place you probably never heard of and their tea comes from something you probably know how to make at home. But it's totally fine because they are cheap friendly and you know what they are open when others aren't and have seating and tables that aren't cluttered by macbook pros and leachers. I dug the vibe.
author: Greg G.

description:
I love outdoor seating. I also love coffee. These things go together well. Muddy Waters has them. But I dislike being asked every five seconds if I can spare change or cigarettes. I especially dislike it when some guy hands me a month old flier for a new years eve party in late January as if he is promoting and then tries to hit me up for cash. Smooth dude, real smooth. Hence only 4 stars for this Muddy Waters (location location location).

The staff here is interesting. I like the grumpy glasses guy. I once called him out for talking about World of Warcraft in public. For that I apologize grumpy glasses guy. That was mean and you are actually pretty nice. I think there is a girl who works here who also works at good frickin chicken. Why do I mention these random things? I dunno. Can't forget faces I guess.
author: Zac H.

description:
Oh, muddy waters. I used to live right next to the one on Valencia and 24th. I'm not generally a huge fan of the muddy waters conglomerate, but the folks running this location in particular are just really nice and chill. I had an emergency with my phone one time and couldn't make or receive any calls and the lady behind the counter let me use her phone. 

They play cool Arabic music and there is free wifi. Sure, some of the clientele is a little rough around the edges, but it's Valencia and 16th, what do you expect. 

I do like bougie coffee from time to time, no doubt about it...but I appreciate the fact that this is a down to earth, no-frills, no-bullshit coffee shop. In a city where that is getting increasingly harder to find, i'm glad to see that it's always busy.
author: Shannon R.

description: Okay. Very much your traditional hipster coffee shop. The hot chocolate was good, the cake looked pretty amazing, the prices were normal. The vibe is a little grungy, which just isn't my thing. I prefer cozy with less florescent lighting, but that's just me. I'll stop in if I'm in the area as it's convenient and they have hot beverages, however it's not somewhere that I feel like hanging out.
author: Courtney A.

description:
A five-star review earned for entirely different things than what I imagine y'all are looking for in a coffee shop.  Just to guess, you're all looking for tasty coffee and interesting atmosphere and endless free wi-fi (only not with too many people using it, because that'd screw up the interesting atmosphere).  Also you're probably into outdoor seating and occasional live music and frequent casual sex with the sort of people who patronize coffee shops on Valencia.

I wasn't looking for any of those things -- I was looking, in fact, for someplace to change my baby daughter's diaper.  Not the easiest trick, in the Mission, BTW, where your typical restroom is three feet by six feet with no countertop (much less a changing table) and a floor you could use for your senior thesis in epidemiology.

Went in and asked anyway.  They didn't, but within a few minutes (and without being asked) the staff had taken a spare table, pushed it into the bathroom, and even covered it with a couple of cloth towels.  The owner even came by midway through to check whether we needed anything.  Someone else here was complaining about the graffiti in the bathroom -- I'm hardly a fan of taggers, but babies like bright colors and sharp contrasts, and the graffiti in this one goes all the way to the ceiling, so my daughter was delighted -- she sat there and stared raptly at it through a lengthy diaper change.  At this age she can hardly get through even a quick change without fussing, so I was impressed -- I may have to invite some taggers back to our bathroom at home.

Came out, bought some coffee and smiled wanly at nothing in particular for half an hour while drinking it and feeding the baby.  Can't speak to how well priced the place is, but on this occasion it was worth the price and even more worth the tip.  Thanks, guys.  :)
author: Devin C.

description:
I haven't been here in YEARS.

It looks yucky from the outside and generally the clientele outside is a little squiffy.  

But when you're...

a) Groggy and needing a cafe' au lait
b) Desperately trying to stall for more time with a cute boy
C) A coffee fiend

You will eschew your biased opinion that windows should be transparent and adventurously step into Muddy Waters to be greeted by mediocre coffee (no better or worse than their competitors) and a cafe that reminds you of your college's student center.  Now that's ambiance!
author: R M.

description:
5 stars. I said it. 

1 star for wifi and tons of outlets
1 star for lighting over tables and tons of tables, especially in the back for those who want to sit and work for hours, like we did. which actually grants them another star. We were there for HOURS. ....but that would detract from the 3 stars I want to give for the best laugh I have had in a long time.

I SAW NAKED MAN!

Dude stumbled into the buzz-in bathroom. He was in there for over 30 minutes, and we kept hearing banging. WTF? Other lady walks up and knocks cuz she gotta take a wicked yes-yes. We tell her it's occupied, so she sits next to us, right across from the bathroom. That's when it happened...

Dude walked out with nothing but a tee-shirt. My friend immediately reverts to being 5 years old and covers her face with both hands. I look three times and stare. 1 because I saw white leg - laptop was covering the jewels. Then I looks around the laptop. I SAW EVERYTHING!!! Holy Crap! I look at my friend, then I look again, and I catch his little turn, drunkenly slow, and see the white of his arse. I SAW NEKED MAN! NEKED MAN! NEKED MAN! In a cafe?????

He then goes back in, and the lady working there forces him to get up (he passed back out on the floor of the nasty bathroom, behind the door), get dressed, and get out.....But he had to put his shoes on. Does he sit on the chair the lady pulled out for him and put in the corner right next to him? Of course not. That would be too easy. 

He stumbled over with his eau de alchyhol and piss-stained pants and sat right next to....and I mean RIGHT NEXT to my friend.

Just for the show,  5 stars. I don't remember the coffee. I don't remember the  people outside the lady who kicked him out, the lady who had to wee-wee, and the other two girls sitting back there with us. We laughed up a ruckus! OMG Dude walked out of the john butt neked!

Lake Anza. Now this? Where next? Neked people everywhere!
author: MiYong E.

description:
I should have checked the reviews on this place before I went, but I was so hell bent on getting a change of scenery... nevermind that, I should have checked the review first. 

Ups: Free WiFi - this is always good and that's why I gave it 2 stars... It's like signing your name to the SAT's you automatically get a few hundred points. Same, same. 

Down Side: Well, let's start with the fact that nothing about this place says cozy -- not a thing. And I know, I'm supposed to be working not lounging on a the sofa, but I don't know - - I feel like if it's going to be a coffee house I want it to feel home-y... not a half way home-y... which is sort of what this felt like. The guy next to me did start talking on his cell phone, but then continued speaking to himself after he hung up... I know, it's the mission, what did I expect? I was just hoping for minimal crazy. Lastly there was shoddy power - - it flickered quit often and no one really seemed to care... At least the WIFI stayed in tact. 

Not recommended for telecommuters, people who like the Marina, or small children.
author: Jenna G.

description:
Hmm.

Points against:

- The coffee isn't that great.

- I always seem to spill it on myself, which is partly my issue but partly a problem with the lids and cups not fitting together properly.

- The wireless is extremely flakey

- It's not the absolute last stop for coffee before BART (or first upon exiting BART).

- I got a cookie once and DIDN'T FINISH IT. Thinking about it now, I can't imagine how bad a cookie can be that I wouldn't finish it. I mean, I even finish Nutter Butters.

- Once I got hit on by a 74 year old man who smelled like an ass full of beer. He was like "Where are you going?" and I was like "Somewhere away." and he was like "Can I come with you?" and I was like "No." and he was like "Can I buy you a drink instead?" and I was like "No." and then he tried to follow me but I was much too quick for his old smelly ass.

- I keep forgetting that I should just not answer the smelly old men when they talk to me. 

- The last time I got coffee here, I got pooped on by a bird as I was leaving.

Points for:

- I secretly think this one dude who works here is crazy hot. 

Conclusion:

- Will likely continue purchasing coffee here.
author: Liz G.

description: I've come here on & off for decades. I'm finally done once & for all. They are always unfriendly, the ambience is not good, it's not clean, the bathroom is bad, there's only 1/2 & 1/2 out, there's an open sugar container & no sugar substitutes out. But what really irks me is that they always fill the cup 2/3 - 3/4 full even if you say you don't need room for cream. I've stopped returning to places that do this. Coffee is so expensive already - fill the damn cup up!
author: Fidel M.

description:
I've been reading the other posts about Muddy's here, and I'm guessing that y'all haters have moved here relatively recently, like in the last 5 years or so, arriving at 16th and Valencia, the reputed "fun," "cool" and "up & coming" place to be. Welcome to San Francisco! Now please consider moving back to wherever you came from.

Muddy's is solid like a rock. Through all the spasms of gentrification, it has barely changed since I moved in around the corner a decade and a half ago. This gives me comfort.

Staggering home in the morning after my night job in '92, Muddy's was there, Prince Charm the Red Man ranting funny nonsense in the back... In the Mid 90s when I needed to escape my trust-fund bike-messenger roommates, Muddy's was a surrogate living room... Joel, the cool guy at the counter was often kind enough to let me nurse a single cup and read for hours on end while I was unemployed. (And he still works there, for Chrissakes!)

Sure, all the pastries are stale, the bagel-toaster takes 45 minutes, people shoot up in the constantly malfunctioning lavatory and newspapers are strewn everywhere. The regular who moos like a cow because of a health condition can be a maddening annoyance, too.

But this refreshingly perverse atmosphere drives off most of the slick-dressed laptop-toting jackasses that have overrun all the other local cafes, making it a little island of dilapidated calm, a tidepool outside the turbulent ocean of douche that the Mission has become. And the coffee is made from Jehova's own nuclear fuel rods! I love this goddamn place, and I worry for its continued existence in the present social/commercial climate.

Seriously, if you can't deal with a few junkies and crazies at your local independent coffee shop, what are you living in the city for? Go back to the suburbs. Move back in with your parents. They'll protect you.
author: David M.

description:
Went to this place late one evening for a snack and some reading. Good bagels and hot chocolate. Plenty of space.

Can't comment on the restroom situation mentioned in the other reviews...

There's free wifi
author: Marc L.

description: Great space and service. Lots of room and outlets if you need to work. A chill atmosphere and the people working there are really kind.
author: Tamara V.

description:
I used to LOVE getting coffee here!
Very consistent and strong coffee, what else matters?
Well, if it does, they're very nice at all hours, they're hip and easy-going, they're affordable, and they make all the standard cafe lunch and breakfast fare.
Their sugar is a bit tricky to deal with (think ketchup bottle).
It's pretty spectacular.
But sadly I quit caffeine, so my review is based solely on the happy memory of a good caffeine buzz.
author: Theo R.

description: The location and atmosphere is awesome but I have to give it 2 stars because they only take cash and the barista assumed that I wanted a medium iced coffee when I only had a measly $1.75 for a small! In my book, I find that so rude! As a person that works in the service industry, to be specific I work in a metal tube at an altitude of 37,000 ft., I don't assume that the guest wants ice with their apple juice or a coffee with no sugar or cream! Don't make assumptions, muddy water!!!
author: Amy C.

description: If you want to be welcomed with a huge smile every morning and a customized coffee with words written in mousse by Nadja, that's the place you wanna go to. Great coffee, wi-fi connection and the nicest staff I've seen in SF!
author: Val M.

description:
Chainsmokers and rehabbers alike love the coffee here. It's potent, I'll give them that.

A charming place, full of charact---lowlifes.
author: Jeremy W.

description:
The art that this place hangs on its walls is worth three stars alone.  It's not always great, but it's usually interesting.  And they change it often enough that you don't get sick of it, or at least I don't.

In terms of coffeehouses, this part of Valencia Street isn't the ideal location for one, especially if you're using a laptop (think theft), but the vibe in here is nice, if a little bit cold, literally.
author: John S.

description:
A friend and I met here to get a little work done.  It's located by my favorite intersection in the Mission - 16th and Valencia.

Dive is the only way to describe this cafe.  No frills, dark, slightly angry, while still really comfortable.  

Free WiFi and yummy chocolate chip peanut cookies.
author: Jen T.

description: The coffee is pretty good, but I really like that it is spacious and the people there all seem relaxed. A lot of the more popular places in SF (four barrel, tartine, the la bolounge series, and blue bottle) are all hectic and you feel rushed when you're trying to relax and enjoy your time.
author: Brandon R.

description:
Not cozy, no service with a smile. The americano I ordered wasn't fantastic but was definitely good. A solid americano. Kind of turned off that they don't have any sugar substitutes. 

The art on the walls was very weird and regardless of temperature, the place was cold. I'm glad it was there to provide the coffee I needed after dinner but I don't see myself returning.
author: Jen S.

description:
A piece of advice for people who go to this Muddy Waters: hold on to your shit. 

I was waiting for a friend there on Saturday evening and had my cell phone stolen right in front me by a drunk woman who came in off the street, got in my face and took my phone. I didn't realize what had happened until she was out the door. She had come in earlier to bother some other people at a different table and then she left. The first time I put my phone in my lap. So yes, it was stupid of me to leave my phone on the table the second time she came in while I was reading so I could wait for my friend's call. But then again, who expects to have their shit stolen right in front of them in a coffee shop???

I am giving this place two stars instead of one because the baristas let me use their phones to call the cops. That was quite nice of them. But they also didn't seem too surprised at what had happened, so I bet sketchy/scary people come in off the street a lot and they just can't/don't do anything about it.

I have always come to this place in the past to kill time if I'm waiting for someone. The bathroom has been nasty but the coffee's fine and they have free papers to read and Internet if you need it. I used to think of it as a good evening refuge but now I've changed my mind. From now on, I might head around the corner to Pancho Villa's, where they have a security guard standing at the door.
author: Molly T.

description:
Exactly what I look for in a cafe: Dry, smells like coffee, clean, and the computer users are segregated from the rest.

Exactly what I avoid in a cafe: Inattentive staff that would prefer to finish their conversation with their friend and drink their coffee over taking an order from a wet and cold newbie that just came in from the torrents of rain sheeting down from the heavens.

The coffee was good, the place was warm, and I was in a great mood, so it was all copacetic.
author: Dave M.

description:
All around good coffee house.  Good (but not great coffee), various coffee drinks, juices, muffins, cookies, cakes, bagels, bagel sandwhiches, central location, atm, 3 internet stations, a galaga game .. and ...

Free wireless (no password)

3/5 coffee
3/5 atmosphere
3/5 service
3/5 food
4/5 value
author: chad n.

description:
They let me into their bathroom when I had no where else to go.

The mandatory you-use-the-shitter-you-buy-something was a bagel. It was just crispy enough, had the right amount of c. cheese, and did not taste like a sponge (you hearing this, Noah's??).

And again, they let me into their bathroom, when I had nowhere else to go but my shorts. And I'm not quite that 16th and Mission, not yet anyway.

Craptacular.
author: Chris R.

description:
Three stars only because this place makes for great people watching. Schizophrenics, junkies, schizophrenic junkies, people who think a bath leads to demonic possesion, all of them here. I could sit here all day and watch them.

Well, I could if the coffee was decent and not served to me by the too cool for f'n school guys who somehow think slinging coffee makes you a badass.
author: Tom W.

description:
Friendly service and a short line are the only real draws here, besides the fact that it is two blocks closer than Ritual to my house. Otherwise it is not so special. Not very clean, and worst of all, no Splenda or non-fat milk!!!
It is a lot less sceney that Ritual, which could be a draw, depending on what you are looking for.
author: Cyrelle D.

description:
I had forgotten about this place until I was forced to revisit the swill they dispense.  This place sucks.  I could go on and on about all the ways this place sucks, but I wont...just don't go there.  
The other locations suck too, when it comes to coffee, but are slightly less gross.  Still, just say no to Muddy Waters coffee.
author: Nilu r.

description:
Okay, admittedly this place is a good one because its open LATE..  or later than the average coffee joint.

What sucks about this place is that the coffee tastes like its been charred first, then brewed.  Seriously, its REALLY awful.

Stick to the tea.  Its always consistent.
author: Hannah N.

description:
Close to work. Sometimes getting something really simple can take a decade, but generally they are efficient. 

A Dog (The Bounty Hunter) look-alike hangs out on the tables outside. He cracks me up and makes my morning when the coffee isn't strong enough.
author: haley d.

description: There was enough seating and outlets all around which made charging my phone when it was about to die a god send. The coffee was pretty good and strong which was a nice surprise. A better coffee spot in the mission for sure.
author: Kate D.

description:
Mouthy workers, yuppie-proof, good coffee.
Perfect.
author: Mer S.

description: Somewhere buried underneath the Pleistocene layer of fliers you'll likely find my ad looking for roommates to start a vegan co-op in 2004. This Muddy Waters is abysmal but at least it doesn't try to be anything it's not.
author: Chris G.

description: Let's start with this...I go to coffee houses to get coffee. This place has good strong coffee and is always entertaining. I can get a quick half hour of work done with the free Wifi, read a paper, or grab a table in the front and people watch the outsiders staring in. The Barista's are friendly enough, I don't need a fake smile to make me feel all warm and fuzzy, I need a quick hello and my coffee hot. The bathroom has gotten some flak below. I will say that the floors are clean when I go, so I can care less about the graffiti on the walls, in fact the OCCUPY comments today were funny as hell. I hope places like this don't disappear, visit on a rainy day and soak up the good Mission District vibes.
author: Kirt V.

description:
I enjoy this place.

I don't make it to the mission during the daylight hours very often but when I do I always make a pit stop here.

I have met up with an assortment of people from many different backgrounds here and they have all been please by my choice in the meeting place.

Hot chocolate here is very worthy of praise, and the staff is just cool, laid back with no worries.
author: Diana D.

description: Lots of fun character in the cafe. Really love the vibe, and the food and drink are very good. Consistent, good every time. The staff is also very welcoming and aim to please. Good prices as well!
author: Zack I.

description:
Is Muddy Waters a front for drugs?  White slavery?  Tunnel to Mexico?

Probably not.

The point is that it's not a "Coffee House".  It's something else.  I just don't know what.
author: Michael F.

description:
This place really doesn't have any redeeming qualities. The coffee really isn't bad and the place's tables aren't sticky, but:

- The people here are almost scary. This isn't character, this is BYOK(nife). 
- The bathroom is a single unit you have to be buzzed into. This doesn't sound bad until you are in there and get buzzed in on by a local rehabber/continuing crackhead.
- There are few outlets to plug into.
author: Eston B.

description: Prices are reasonable,  great location, really peaceful atmosphere.  Staff was kind of ehh whatever, but the coffee was great! I'll be coming back for coffee and free wifi for sure.
author: Heather M.

description:
i do a lot of freelance work, and love Muddy's because of all the coffee shops near my house that are maybe a bit more fancy on the decor/atmosphere, when i come here i feel like i can GET WORK DONE!

--lots of tables. i feel like there is enough "room", even when there are a lot of people.

--i've never had an issue with the WiFi (i noticed my computer was slow once, and checked to find two people connected to my machine. my fault.)

--good music, and if i don't like what's playing, my ipod at a moderate volume fills in fine.

--coffee = ROCKET FUEL! i drink a boatload of coffee and have a ridiculous caffeine tolerance, but still, theirs never fails to lift the fog. it's not Philz, but it tastes just fine to me.

--bathroom has been cleaned up in the past months, thank you!

--two lady baristas are always kind, and do a nice job when i ask for a bagel with hummus and tomatoes. (add pepper. choose nice tomatoes. etc.). i DO wish they had a couple more food options, though i recently tried the oat cakes (those things that look like hockey pucks) and the apricot one was super good!! pleasant surprise.

if you're looking for the coffee shop equivalent of a night club, this is not the place. if you want stiff coffee and/or a functional office away from home with some personality, Muddy's is perfect.

cash only, FYI
author: Domini D.

description: I don't know who the baristas are on other nights but i usually drop by muddy waters before yoga at yoga kula on wednesday s and the gal behind the counter on wed nights is the bomb.  i can get a chai in 2 minutes plus she remembers you after a handful of visits and has yet to scowl at me.  three cheers for fast and friendly.
author: Jen I.

description:
If you ever just need a good cup of coffee without all the bullshit in central mission-this is your go-to place. 

Or, you could go to Ritual and have some jerk who thinks he's henry rollins refuse to give you a double shot of espresso to go.

Is it strange I want a double shot of espresso to go. Too bad. That's what I want. 

I would never get a double shot of espresso to go here, but that's not the point.

This is a good working class place with fantastic baristas.
author: stub s.

description:
I was freezing in the rain one night and this place saved me.
Yes, saved me. 
Hence the stars. 
Warm food, free wi-fi and GOOD coffee saved the day. 

Plus, the atmosphere is interesting. People who aren't completely absorbed in their laptops/work and baristas who don't bug you to leave gives it four stars in my book.
author: Amy S.

description:
Interior too bright and drab all though they do have som eold 80's arcade game.

The guy who works nights is a little dry but love his attitude! Typical mission attitude, if you've lived there far any amount of real time!

He makes great coffee!
author: Jason K.

description:
Decent coffee, lots of outlets/tables, free WiFi and open late! 

A coffee place that even the homeless can hang out, grab a cup of ice at and use the crappiest bathroom I've seen is fine with me.  I just take my bowel and urinary needs elsewhere.

I am a fan.
author: Christina C.

description:
Another Friends of the Urban Forest Saturday morning rendezvous.  I guess I would have never come in here otherwise, given the 2.5 star average.  But then I would have missed out on some awesome coffee.  Yes, the atmosphere is grungy, much like Soma Coffee, but the coffee is way better than that.  Not quite Cafe Bello good, but still.  I do suggest that they get more than one barista (especially since she has to make the bagels too), because the line gets long at the 9:00 rush.

So I say don't listen to the haters.  But then, I was here on an I'm-riding-my-bike-around-the-city-fixing-trees high, so take my sunny review with a grain of salt too.  We all know that moods can make a 1-star difference even in the most objective of reviewers.
author: Wes M.

description:
There are signs everywhere asking you to pay for internet, so I paid 2.50 for 15 minutes so I could check my e-mail, only to find out it's actually free when you log in.  Great.

The asian woman behind the counter was extremely pushy and rude, anxiously trying to get to the next customer when there was only one person in line behind me.  

I ordered a Masala Chai and it was filled to the brim so in my rush to get away from the counter it spilled on my fingers.  

The atmosphere is cool albeit somewhat disorganized.  The tables and chairs are simply strewn about in no particular order so it could be a little chaotic to find a place to sit but I had no problem. 

If you couldn't tell by the tone of this review, this place gave me some bad vibes.  There are much better options in the Mission.  I won't come back here.
author: Aaron V.

description:
Blech!

This place always makes me feel kinda icky, in the gutter-punk gross type of way.   I usually leave with an odd compulsion to scrub my hands. repeatedly.   

The only reason to go here is if you're in a huge rush and it's convenient, otherwise, please spend your money somewhere else.
author: Shayna N.

description:
Most of the people who are giving bad reviews like their coffee houses to make them feel better about themselves, as if they were cooler just for going into one.

This is the place for straight up great Mocha, if you want to meet the Mission's greatest characters, although some may try to sell you 3 hot XBOX360's, and if you want to chill.

Go to L's Caffe to show your girlfriend how cool and trendy you are in the Mission District. Go to Muddy's to show her how tough Mission is and how bad ass you are.
author: Haz O.

description:
2.2.2007
8:30PM

I'm not a coffee expert...but i drink at LEAST a cup a day, from my local Starbucks on Mission (cross street Beale) where I work.  My buddy Daniel will never step foot in a Starbucks but it's my favorite place to buy coffee; consistently good.  

I was walking through my neighborhood and came across Muddy Waters...and ya...should have kept walking.  There was a pretty girl sitting outside of the shop playing her xylophone (damn you!) and looking back, was the ONLY reason why I stepped foot intothis place.  DIRTY....DISORGANIZED...and greeted by a stone-faced Batista whose facial expressions resembled a 90 year old woman who just had her entire face botoxed....

Don't go here...unless you HAVE to...
author: William R.

description:
latte was merely ok.
service was merely ok.

It's a shame...I like to support the local places.   I'll stick to ritual coffee
author: Matt V.

description:
I am a coffee addict.  Like I have trouble getting dressed in the morning without a cup.  Luckily when I crash at my friends place in the mission I sleep in my clothes so there's no problem there.

Naturally I grab a cup to sip while waiting for the 22 and this seems to be the only place between his place and the bus stop. 

Let me put it this way:  I would rather have no coffee at all than pay money for this garbage.  I gave it a couple of tries before admiting defeat.  Man that bus ride sucks so hard.
author: Rachel N.

description:
It's decent and close.

I wanted a bagel and an Americano one fateful morning. I wound up here, having used their "public" bathroom several times before I lived in the area. 

I brought my laptop and set up camp. Ordered my goods and I was served.

You only get one type of milk. I had to search for the sugar.

The bagel was delicious, but I think I paid more for it than I do at work during the week in the FiDi.

But, as far as coffeeshops go...I prefer this over the sleek, overly-clean spots popping up around. 

And they have neat graffiti in the bathroom. Score.
author: Danyell K.

description:
Coffee was tolerable.  Nothing to crow about.  But, the counterperson was quite efficient -- he managed to serve the both of us without uttering one word.

It impressed me.
author: Happy C.

description:
Are you there for the "feel of it" or the "Taste of it"?  If you want great  tasting coffee this is the place.  If you want a better that gritty locale this is it.  If you want starbucks, well, go to starbucks.

Get a pound of dark, oily, like the ocean at night, coffee.  Grind and brew and sip what coffee is supposed to taste like.  Ebony heaven.
author: Dan W.

description: If you are a coffeeshop that advertises free wi-fi, you'd better have functional wi-fi available or know how to at least perform the most basic of steps like power-cycling the router to make a minimal effort.  The woman manning the register with the black hat and glasses just waved her hand when I told her the wifi was down and mumbled something about a "new system" that "isn't reliable", and claimed she didn't know where the router was to try power-cycling it.  Also, the latte she served me was lukewarm.  Not acceptable.
author: Ziggy S.

description:
I went here almost every day when I worked in the Mission.  One thing's for sure - this cafe is very San Francisco.  

I'll admit that Muddy Waters isn't the cleanest cafe in the world.  There are definitely crazy people hanging out front much of the time.  But the coffee is good, and the baristas are really friendly.

Better bagels than Katz!  But (and this is why I took a star off) they use American cheese on their egg and cheese bagels.

Try the spanikopita.  It's good.
author: Amy S.

description: You can probably notice from my reviews that I love coffee houses and am generally easy to please in this category. Give me a comfy place to sit, good coffee, a selection of nosh-ables, and free wifi and I will give you lots of business and lots of shiny yelp stars in return. Unfortunately, this place does not have any of the above mentioned coffee house qualities. The seats are uncomfortable, the food is usually stale, the coffee is just decent, the cream and sugar station is a gross mess and the wifi never seems to work when I'm there. Plus it's cash only which is just annoying. I've given this place a second try and I'm disappointed again. There are too many other great options in the neighborhood to even consider returning.
author: Marissa P.

description: tasty cafe. great ambient, very relaxing, nice music, ok service.
author: Jm J.

description: The cappuccino I ordered was mediocre at best, and the atmosphere isn't great, but the wifi is reliable and it was easy enough to grab a seat on a Sunday afternoon.
author: Vishay N.

description:
As always, I'm looking for that perfect place that has a good environment to hunker down and get some work done on my computer. So, the most important thing that I look for in a place is a comfortable, quiet environment (free WiFi goes without saying) followed by all the casual stuff like vibe and quality of coffee

Located in the heart of the mission... the somewhat grungy decor makes it a place where people come to hang out and chill rather than click away on their laptops.

However, it is split into a some what more lively section at the front and a relatively quiet seating section behind the coffee bar. 

I like the coffee, but I keep having to profess that it doesn't take much for me to like a coffee. That being said:

Yays:
1. Free WiFi
2. Lots of  electrical outlets
3. Several seating sections, front and back
4. Decent enough coffee

Boos:
1. Can get a bit noisy at times (I guess thats what you get when you are on Mission)
2. No credit cards

Its pretty good, but there is nothing about it that makes it really standout for me..
author: Krishnan S.

description:
if you don't like muddy's... you must have just moved to the mission.

i am sure many people will be happy when valencia st. becomes a melrose clone. 

and then when the mission is the new marina, the tenderloin will be the new place to ruin.

and about the surly guy who works at night, well he is just that. and by the way, he takes his job seriously and makes a great drink. i go often at night and he makes me laugh every time i am in there. he is just letting the world know it is his day. cafe workers and comic book store dudes are infamous for their 'tude. 

do you really prefer the " completely uncomfortable in their own skin, pretentious creeps" at 4 barrel!? they act like royalty despite the fact that they are clearing 25 grand a year. and i don't know if the girls who work there act dumb or they just are dumb/stoned?
author: midas r.

description: I like Muddy Waters because it is the typical Mission Coffeehouse...but is not. The spaciousness of the back area reminds me more of indie coffee houses in the Midwest or Arizona. The tea is the standard amazing Mighty Leaf. I'd give it more stars except that today the whole coffeehouse smells of Muni.
author: Cameron K.

description:
The coffee is good, I like the atmosphere, and the location is really convenient, so I go here pretty often. The service is not the most friendly though.

There was one day I walked in and the barista was wearing a T-shirt saying "Die Hipster Scum". As my brother eloquently put it, "Pot, kettle. Kettle, pot."
author: Frank T.

description: Coffee was okay, but too hot and only half/half for creamer (i like nonfat milk).  The bran muffin was super good, and the free wireless was good.  Would be four stars if they took a credit card.
author: Josh T.

description: I go there mostly for the free wifi, many electrical outlets  and huge tables in the backroom. I could not care less for the coffee or food at this place.
author: Nilesh D.

description: darkest dark muddiest mud coffee...mission vibe and feel...larger wooden aged lounging interiors...front or back...small outside or large inside....dive cafe?...possible...simple open container granulated sugar and cream..nothing more...nothing else...not liking coffee, but lounging atmosphere and rest looking promising.....
author: Hen A.

description:
granted im not a big coffee drinker, but the coffee here is so-so

staff is incredibly nice and friendly, atmosphere is the typical mission crowd
author: Art A.

description: I like this place for a couple reasons.  One, Devon rules.  Two, the mochas are really good. Three, there isn't a line out the door or that too-cool-for-school element present at other Valencia coffee establishments.  Sure, there are a couple of customers that may actually live there.  And the bus stop and chairs outside are popular hangouts for some ragged-looking locals.  One of them told me I was really pretty the other day, so I can't complain.  Complements are the quickest way to this heart of stone.
author: Mike A.

description: the essence of the blend of the the best/worst that sf has to offer, love the quirky/sketchy clientel, servers with some attitude, slight aroma of the street and a old school Galaga Game where the fire button doesn't always work.  What more could you ask for?  I would gladly sit there to people watch before a flick at the Roxie, but one star off because I probably wouldn't bring the kids.
author: Bruce R.

description:
decent espresso, rickety chairs and a goth vampire-type sitting next to us eavesdropping on our conversation. i think that says it all.

my friend ade bought one of those chocolate and almond covered sesame biscuits and it was pretty tasty.
author: May T.

description: This place has such potential.  Great location, good hot chocolate, lots of room, and lots of outlets.  It is actually a quite comfortable place to be and could have been an ideal place to get some work done.  If the advertisted free wi-fi was more reliable, I would have stayed much longer and ordered another menu item, probably a price one.
author: Sonia K.

description: wifi. excellent mission district ambience. over-roasted (burned) coffee gets 7/10.
author: Steve F.

description: I just like this coffee shop a lot for some reason. It's a pretty standard rag-tag coffee shop with shabby furniture, but it has really fresh coffee and the moistest coffee cake I've ever tried. They also have an old school Pac-Man table console, which totally kicks ass.
author: Michael E.

description: above average temp on the 2nd of November somewhere around 70 led to an ice coffee and a cookie. Mission accomplished
author: Chris W.

description: good coffee cheap, nice folks. close to bart
author: Leigh-mcinnis G.

description: Muddy Waters is a change of pace from all the clean, sleek coffeehouses that are popping up nowadays.  The coffee's actually okay.  And seeing the clientele that come in can be entertaining at times.  But this one on Valencia isn't a place I'd want to stay in for very long.
author: Marsha Z.

description: Good enough! The decor is indeed muddy, somehow: nicked brown booths span the wall, streaming into nicked brown chairs and tables. But you can sit here forever without being bothered. Work or socialize. The food and drinks are good enough. This place isn't great in any way (except, actually, the music they play--the Moroccan employees play catchy ethnic music, and the punk brown dude plays e.g. Morphine), yet I end up coming here a lot.
author: Charlie Bolognese Z.

description: Free wi-fi and the most chocalicious mocha around, Muddy Waters has my heart.  Even at 6 AM when it's indecent to be awake Muddy Waters makes the world a better place.  It's grungy.  It's got some colorful clientele.  And it has an old-school pacman video table.  A perfect combo is the mocha and a peanutbutter chocolate chunk cookie.  Split it with your sweetie and happiness ensues.
author: Tracy E.

description: Coffee? Cant get enough of it. Being introduced to her dog by a crazy lady dressed as a clown? I think I've had my fill, thank you. This place has always been marginally dirty and chock full of nutjobs. Fine with me. The coffee is pretty average, but does the job. Most times I require little more than snappy service and average coffee, so there.
author: Steven C.

description: They should call this Rat Hole Cafe. Last time I'm buying anything there. Too much money for a coffee and a cookie, and the place looks so run down. Would it kill the owners to buy a freaking can of paint???? Just because it's called muddy waters doesn't mean that everything should be painted dark brown.
author: Gabriel T.

description: I like the free wi-fi and the good selection of teas and snacks. Don't like the fact that the wi-fi is hella slow, however, and that the bathroom is extremely nasty.
author: Chaney K.

description: Crazy bums sitting on the bench outside, dirty floors all around, and a bathroom that only a mother with hepatitis C could love - It must be Muddys at 16th street!  This is a great place to study (or yelp/myspace while you pretend to study) on any given night of the week - they offer free wi-fi and a nice quite environment. Just DON'T bring your date here (unless they are as fabulous as mine was,  in which case you'll have fun anyway).  Oh and Try the hot apple cider when they have it in season - DIVINE.
author: Matt G.

description: Looking for coffee to get you through that first hour of work?  How about the 2nd?  Have you found one that will actually hold you well into lunch?  I don't know about you, but heck ya, I sure did!  Two days later and I'm still feeling the lingering effects of that jitterness.  If you can give coffee a rating, Muddy Waters would surpass R.  I can't get over the fact that my meager $1.75 got me that cup of utter goodness (not to mention power!).  Mmmmm.
author: Swetha G.

description: I don't know if this and the other Muddy Waters are under common ownership.  My guess is they are.  If not, someone should sue, because they are just like each other.  As a result, and from someone who is pro-recycling, I will recyle the review that I gave that other Muddy Waters-- "This place looks dirty, the decor is scary, and the coffee is just as good as the name suggests."
author: John D.

description: It's good for what it is.  Yummy carot cake and good teas.  Bathroom is violent.
author: Susan K.

description:
There was no line at the bar when I walked in, so I ordered an Americano from the bored looking barista. Since they don't take cards, I had to use their in-shop ATM. The barista made the drink and I asked about a pastry in the glass display case. The guy muttered something about coconut, which sounded appetizing. I ordered one and the guy microwaved it back to life. As soon as I bit into it, I realized it was some musty, mold-tasting spinach-n-cheese pastry. I'm pretty accepting of food that's a little passed its prime and I have to say, this was bad enough I actually threw it away. I wish I could say the coffee was the saving grace of the experience, but I couldn't really taste the coffee over the strong taste of plastic, presumably from the cup. After a few sips, I tried dressing it up with some creamer and sugar, neither of which could cover up the potent taste and smell of plastic. As a side note, the drink preparation area consisted of a large pitcher (the kind most restaurants use for iced tea) filled with half and half, a 2-gallonish sized tub labeled "Brown Sugar" half empty with a community spoon dropped in it, and a syrup carafe filled with regular sugar. None of the options looked vaguely appealing to me, especially not the brown sugar. 

To top off the experience, four sips into my drink, the barista decided to take a smoke break so he walked to the door of the place and lit up, letting his cigarette smoke meander back into place. After the second sip of plastic coffee + cigarette smoke, I was done. I trashed the drink along with the moldy spinach and bailed. I passed the barista on the way out and he just looked bored. Total time in the place--ten minutes, roughly. I won't be making a return trip.
author: Jackson G.

description: It's a typical cafe with a typical menu. The only thing that kept me from loving it was the pretentious barista who seemed pissed at everything. He was not nice. At all. I'll probably give it another try, though. Maybe he was just having an extra bad day.
author: Jennifer H.

description: Strong coffee--check!  It's a great place to grab a cup while you're in the Mission.  Not quite as cheap as other places, but worth it if you're already going down valencia on your way to the bart at 16th and mission.  CASH ONLY, though... bummer.
author: Susan D.

description: This place is creepy, an uneasy mix of posers and straight-out crazy people. Three stars for the fact that you can sit here and mooch off the wifi for as long as you like, or as long as your throat remains unslit.
author: Allison L.

description: Ok, so I've only had the coffee here, and it isn't any better or worse than any of the other local coffee joints. However, this place seriously needs to be renovated... its downright dirty inside, and the service is not particularly friendly or attentive. I want to support local independent businesses -- but if I have to choose between an independent cafe that is a dump, has an indifferent staff, and serves products are lacking in quality... I'll go to Star***** over that any day.
author: Sunny Y.

description: It has a nice coffee shop feel, it can be pretty loud and noisy. There are some really interesting people who walk in (the last time I went in, someone had to call the cops on this guy cause he was getting in a full on fight with the guy at the cashier while I was trying to order...awkwwwaaard). The coffee is just alright. I wasn't too impressed to be perfectly honest. I can't really stand to be here for more than a half an hour because of all the ruckus. So I usually end up calling my friend Matt and walking over to his place to watch the Office with a bitter white mocha in hand.
author: Shereen R.

description:
UPDATE:

I just downgraded them from two stars to one.  they've now stopped distributing the cup heat protectors and lectured me when i asked for one.  "you can have one this time" i was told, "but save it, you will not be given another one."  She's right, because i'm never going back there.   
* * * *
I like their house coffee a lot.  I don't like having to ask them for Splenda and whole milk and having them be irritated with me for it.  There are a couple of folks behind the counter who are really nice, one who is pleasant, another who is a straight up asshole, working at night.  He was irritated that I even showed up to order, expressing supreme irritation that a customer had arrived and he had to get up and serve.  I walked out and got coffee later on at Starbucks - they were extremely friendly per usual, even if their corporate master told them to be.   I've been back to this Muddy's severly times as it's convenient, but never at night when i see asshole "working."  I don't understand why, like every other coffee house I've ever been to in my 33 years of life, they don't leave out the milk and artificial sweetner.  Especially if it's such a hassle to put out when asked.   

Why Muddy Waters on Valencia?  

And please fire the dick.
author: Mike C.

description: Open late, drinks are not too bad, and close to the wild Valencia/16th four corners. Some honest attitude from some people that work there and occasional characters from SRO housing nearby make it an even more interesting experience. I like!
author: Dmitriy S.

description: After dinner, we came here. I didn't order anything but it was alright. It seemed a little dark in there. It was cold. But it was busy with people.  I have nothing else to say because I didn't order anything.
author: Mel P.

description: I came in here, hoping to find a quick breakfast bite. I've only ordered one thing - which is darn good - the sun-dried tomatoes cream cheese on bagel. I don't care for the decor nor the vibe it gives off...I wouldn't be sipping my coffee in the shop.
author: Audrey L.

description: A coffee place thats open past 10? Sweet. On the nights when I don't to go out for an alcoholic beverage, I'm usually craving some coffee. And its so hard to find a coffee shop open past 10 anywhere (besides Starbucks... NEXT). Coffee is decent, and the price was pretty good too. Sucked not having a place to sit down since it was (apparently) board game night and there was some Boggle competition going on, and another game with trains (WTF?). Ambiance was good, I'd come back for sure, maybe not on a game night though unless I can find a way to make a word out of FPNYEI.
author: Rocky K.

description: Coffee lovers rejoice!! The coffee here is off the heezy! However, service is blah. My poor hubby is one of the most patient people I've ever met. I think he waited LONG after people after him got their coffee. 15 minutes later he reminded them they never got his espresso. I came back another day... no one in line... and not a care in the world to the guy with glasses ringing me up. But as soon as I started digging in my massive purse that could fit my family in it... I got the coldest stare from him. Okay okay... so it took me a solid 45 seconds to find 2 dollars for him. But it's not like he had something to do. OH yeah he did. He took my money and then quickly took a sig and lit one up outside. of course ..........
author: flo t.

description: Good food, large space, great location. The restroom is a little frightening but hey, it's the Mission...
author: Pax G.

description: ok i just stopped in on my way to the dentist.  should have stopped in at the ritual instead.  the coffee was plan bad.  not srong but very bitter.  i couldn't even finish it and that is saying alot.  service is abrasive as well.  too many good coffee houses in this hood to go here.  a mistake
author: brian l.

description: A decent cup of joe - haven't tried any of the fancy stuff. Nice space in the back of the place to sit without it being too crowded. Worth a visit.
author: Judy L.

description: OK heres the deal. Coffee is GREAT and the place if funky to just sit and watch people.  But if you want to order something to eat be well WARNED! I ordered a smoke salmon bagel, it had more cream cheese on it to sink a rubber duck and only ONE slice of smoked salmon. NO extras, NO tomatoe, NO capers, NO lettuce....Very SAD! For $4.75 I could have gone around the corner and got myself a huge burrito or sandwich.
author: Patricia - Trixie M.

description:
ugh. 
nuthn much to do xmas day.
ugh. ugh. ugh.
a weird place, in a not-so-good way
author: Today Y.

description:
i like this place.  i pass it on my way in the mornings and there is never a line, the chai is not too sweet, and most importantly, they froth their milk real good.  also it is cheaper than peet's.

update:  extra half-star because this morning the woman at the register asked where i work because she likes that i always 'dress sharp' yessssssss.
author: ali l.

description: I came in with my laptop and wanted to find a place to sit where I could plug it in.   There wasn't much for electrical outlets and all the onces in existence were being used up.  But the barista was like, 'eh, just use the game as a table."  So I got to set up shop on that flat video game in the front room!  That made me feel cool.
author: Levi B.

description: This is the first time I have been at Muddy Waters and used my laptop.  I have had coffee here and once tried to use my Palm Pilot on wifi and did not have much luck.  Today, I camped here with a cup of coffee and it worked out great.  The connection is great and they have lots of seats with plugs.  The coffee is great though most basic house coffee is pretty okay everywhere.  It is a beautiful day outside and I have been here a couple of hours.  The traffic here fluctuates and so does the noise level but the noise blends with the boombox music and very easy to block out.  I had a productive time and shall return if in the area.
author: Cush D.

description:
Muddy's is the only coffee shop I go to in the Mission. It's really the only place where you can get an excellent soy capuccino - at least if you get the guy that works nights, who clearly knows what he's doing. You can't really get soy foam like that anywhere else on that side of the bridge. He's efficient, respectful, and makes great coffee - the most important qualities in a barista, in my book.

It's also close to BART and spacious, so a great place to meet up with people and have (small) meetings, which I do whenever I end up in SF.
author: Isabel P.

description: I go here out of necessity because its close to work and i'm often cutting it close in terms of time, but sometimes I get so annoyed!  I can't tell you how many times I've come in when the older of the two women is working (love the younger one, she actually works) and the counter is completely deserted.  I often stand there for three or four minutes looking around before she decides to amble on over and take my order, which always take far longer than it needs to because she lives in perpetual slow-motion mode.  I actually think that when I am visibly in a hurry (you know the body language- fingers tapping, anxious glances toward the door and the clock...) she finds ways to prolong the process by deciding "now would be a good time to slice the cream cheese, before I serve the person staring at me from the other side of the counter".  Grr!  The coffee itself is mediocre but the service is what really irks me....
author: Alicia B.

description:
The coffee sucks.  The chai sucks.

If you're in the mood for a reasonable bagel where the cream cheese is piled on, however, this is the place to go.

If you're in the mood for a place where no one talks to you and everyone is busy doing things on their own laptops and you just want to get some work done, this is definitely the place to go.

Or you could go to the library that is one block away.
author: Aamir V.

description: The ultimate Mission experience... Clientele runs from strung-out junkies to Harvard grad students (I wrote half of my dissertation there- and yes, I bought lots of stuff to earn my table time). More than any other cafe I've made my "home," this place has a true cross-section of the types that make the Mission what it is. The Moroccan lady who runs the morning and afternoon shift calls everyone honey and often knows what you're going to order before you even say it. The angry guy with the "die hipster scum" t-shirt who often works evenings adds his own charm (and makes Muddy Waters the only cafe in the neighborhood where I've seen a regular black employee). You'll often see zine artists or half-crazed poets at work, and the free wi-fi almost always works. In an age when the Valencia corridor is filling up with gentrified hipster cafes. MW is an oasis. Plus, the coffee is pretty good!
author: Alexander A.

description: I have been coming to this coffee house for years and not once have i experienced the bad service, bad coffee, or bad environment all of you yelpers are ranting about. Muddy Waters has great coffee...what more do you people want!? And yes, it may not be as clean as your local Starbucks, but hey if that's what you're looking for then go there. Not only is this location perfect because it is so close to everything it really does represent just about everything a San Francisco coffee shop should offer.  I consider Muddy Waters my home away from home, and if the rest of you don't...well..then I'm sure Starbucks will make you feel all warm and fuzzy inside
author: sara z.

description: there are always a shitload of miscreants outside of this cafe. their coffee and lattes are good, though, and it seems like a cool place to sit.
author: Sara M.

description: I was unimpressed by the baked goods I tried here, and the coffee's unmemorable.  The place gets three stars for free wifi, hours that extend a bit later than many of its coffeeshop brethren in the area, and most of all the crowd.  There is always someone interesting to watch, and almost always at least one baffling interaction (either between two patrons or a patron and the barista) that I like to put my own interpretation on from afar.
author: S P.

description: a great spot for studying/reading. the coffee isnt bad either. the place for sure has a funky feel to it. very old looking tables and chairs, but the service is good and in a way so is the atmosphere. sometimes its a bit too crowded for my taste but its never very noisy (at least in my experience). i hear the wifi is great there too.
author: Andrew D.

description: I'd return for a coffee to go and possibly sit outside if it's nice. Otherwise, I would not come here to read for leisure or study- It's noisy and distractingly busy and it stinks. The bathroom... I do not care to go into detail in lieu of bringing back repressed memories.
author: Vanessa R.

description: this place PISSES ME OFF. i even gave it like 8 tries because it's close to my house. on the worst try, they completely forgot about my coffee, pretended they didn't see me, and then didn't apologize when i reminded them. on the best try, they didn't actively piss me off but failed to impress me. maybe it's their ridiculously snotty attitudes coupled with poor reading material, charging money for their wireless service, and the bad smell. the best part about it is that if you score an outdoor table, you can get the hell outta there while you drink your (mediocre) coffee.
author: Cristabel L.

description: white guys with laptops get the seating in back, behind the bar, close to the bathroom that you have to get buzzed into. homeless and other down-on-their-heels flaneurs get pride of place, in the front seating area and on the benches out front. the plain black coffee is worth braving the wackiness. drink it somewhere else. anywhere else.
author: michael k.

description: not that great. my chai was very weak, and the piroshki i had was tough. no couch-like seating either... and a pompous feminist was being interviewed about her love of pornography right next to me, which didnt add to the ambiance. terrifying bathroom.
author: Lisa M.
